TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I inform the Senate that the Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories, Senator Faulkner, will be absent from question time today and tomorrow. Senator Faulkner is overseas attending the ministerial segment of the second conference of the parties to the biodiversity convention, which will discuss the negotiation of a protocol on biosafety dealing with the transfer, handling and use of living modified organisms. In Senator Faulkner's absence from question time, Senator Bolkus will take questions on the environment, sport and territories; Senator Ray will act as Manager of Government Business in the Senate and will represent the Minister for Veterans' Affairs; and Senator Schacht will represent Senator Faulkner at the hearings of the Environment, Recreation, Communications and the Arts Legislation Committee into the additional estimates today.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Treasurer. I remind the minister that, when last week's figures showed 740,000 Australians out of work and the position getting worse, Mr Keating, the Prime Minister, said `the economy is in a very nice position'. On what basis did the Prime Minister make those comments, when we have the worst current account deficit in the industrialised world, the second highest real interest rate in the same community and the second highest inflation rate—except for the last three months, when it was the worst in the OECD? What comfort is there for people struggling to deal with rising prices, rising unemployment and uncertainty about their mortgage rates? Doesn't this again demonstrate a Prime Minister—an arrogant Prime Minister—out of touch with the real struggles of ordinary Australians?

—The opposition continues in the role of being a serial assassin on the economy: talking down the Australian economy and undermining confidence. Fortunately, though, for the real economy—not the one that the opposition talks about in here, but the one that actually operates in the Australian community—we see, in terms of the indicators on business confidence and the indicators on consumer confidence, that, while certainly they have dipped a little from a very high spike, nonetheless in historic terms the levels of business confidence in the Australian economy and the levels of confidence exhibited in this economy by consumers remain very high. That may not encourage the opposition, which wants of course to talk down the economy. Nonetheless, the people out there who invest money and the consumers who purchase goods regard the economy as strong and, indeed, the economy is on a sustainable growth path.

PARA.TAB: It is true that the underlying inflation rate has risen a little over the last six months, but it remains at extremely low levels—certainly at extremely low levels compared to the economy that Mr Howard presided over when he was Treasurer in which inflation was at 11.4 per cent, as I recall. Certainly we have broken the back of that. We are combining a solid growth performance with a moderate inflation performance and, for the first time in a generation, have got the levels of growth and inflation under control.

The pick-up in inflation which we have seen comes on the back of four years of sustained economic growth in this country. The national accounts which will be released at the end of this month I believe will show that we have had four years and one quarter of sustained and consecutive economic growth, which will be a new record for Australia.

The other part of this question focused on employment. The recent moderation in employment growth is not unexpected. It follows six months of extraordinary growth in employment. There were 200,000 jobs created in the first six months of this year, which is almost more than the job growth in the last five years of the Howard government put together.

The recent moderation of employment growth has to be seen in perspective. Employment growth for the year so far is around 160,000 new jobs. In any case, employment as an indicator is a lagging indicator. It says to us what has happened; it does not say to us what will happen. Now that the economy has slowed and we have sustainable growth, we expect employment to grow.

There are now a quarter of a million more Australians in work this year than there were at the same time last year. That is because of the sustainable economic growth of this economy, which is, as I say, in inflation terms still at a low level. The fundamentals of this economy are sound. The fundamentals cannot be sabotaged by the serial assassins of the opposition who want to talk the economy down. Business confidence in the economy is high. Consumer confidence is high as well.

We have Access Economics' investment monitor reporting $162 billion worth of new investment projects which are either under construction, planned or under consideration at present. People are committing themselves to that $162 billion worth of investment or are thinking of doing so because of their view of the economy. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —I think I should bring the minister back to the question. We are not talking moderation of employment growth. We are talking rising unemployment; we are talking about the future of 740,000 Australians still out of work. What they want to know is whether it is in fact the case that we do have the second highest real interest rates in the industrialised world—this is under your administration, under your government—the second highest inflation rate in the industrialised world and the worst current account deficit in the industrialised world. These are simple questions—right or wrong?

—Senator Hill wants it both ways. He asked an initial question which strayed right across all the indicators. I answered him on a couple of those indicators, and he changes the question to suit the ones he really wants to focus on. If he wanted a decent answer on those particular things, perhaps he should have asked me about them directly. I repeat: the fundamentals of this economy are sound. We have sustainable economic growth, which is to say the economy is growing, jobs are being created in this economy—

—Mr President, I raise a point of order. This is a classic case where the supplementary question simply repeated three propositions from the original question. They each require a yes or no answer. We are seeking information from the minister. We have put things to him about the abysmal state of the economy in three respects. He is simply being asked to confirm or deny. That is not a difficult thing to do. You have now had enough opportunity to see that he is going to waffle on about the fundamentals. We are interested in three particular questions. It is a very simple matter for you to direct his attention to answering those.
—The supplementary question was clearly related to the original question, which was general. The minister is relevant.

—If one wants to talk about fundamentals, one of the reasons why the current account deficit in Australia is high is that we have been growing so strongly. Because the economy has been growing so strongly, it cannot generate sufficient product within the domestic economy and is sucking in goods from outside. That is one of the reasons why we have a high current account deficit. That is not because the economy is weak; that is because the economy is strong, Senator Hill. Maybe you do not know that. (Time expired)

—My question is also directed to the Minister for Industry, Science and Technology. Is the minister aware of the uncertainty within the Western Australian business community about the so-called second and third wave industrial relations reforms? What are the implications of this uncertainty both for industry in Western Australia and for the wider Australian community?

—I am sure that everyone in the business community in Western Australia and nationally were pleased to see that the Trades and Labour Council of Western Australia and the Western Australian government reached an agreement—not in full, but in part—about withdrawing from legislation some of the more obnoxious and provocative elements of the Western Australian second wave industrial relations changes.

PARA.TAB: What has given rise to continuing anxiety and concern for the Western Australian business community is that the Premier of Western Australia, Dick Court, said at the time in which he withdrew these changes that he was doing so in order to force his legislation through by the end of the year. The industrial relations minister in Western Australia, Mr Graham Keirath, has countermanded that. In the weekend press, the Premier has come out and agreed with Mr Keirath that in fact the real reason why the Western Australian government has done a somersault on its industrial relations legislation is nothing at all to do with its own legislative program but is to do with the federal election.

We have a situation in which the federal coalition and no doubt Mr Howard have prevailed upon the Western Australian government to remove their second wave of legislation and to therefore reduce the provocation to the workers of Western Australia, the consequential disruption to the economy and the consequential loss of faith in the Western Australian economy by investors, both domestic and foreign. They have done so for simply electoral purposes. This is not a clear signal of real intent; it is a signal of deceit—deceit that the changes that have now been withdrawn by the Western Australian government may be held back and then brought forward following a federal election in this country.

That is just the second wave. We know that in the second wave there are quite a number of quite profoundly obnoxious things that even the Western Australian Chamber of Commerce and Industry objected to, the mining industry objected to and the very conservative editorial writers of the West Australian newspaper objected to as well. It seems that these are now being held back to be visited upon the undeserving Western Australian community after a federal election.

That is not to even go to the third wave. Just the other week, on the eve of some of the most sensitive industrial relations negotiations in the state of Western Australia, Mr Keirath, the industrial relations minister, announced that given that they were in negotiations about a second wave, there would be a third wave. This man, who is increasingly seen as an ideologue with nothing more than militant intent to impose his ideology on the community, has created widespread discord in Western Australia.

My concern is the signal this sends to the Australian business community. The Australian business community is aware that the Western Australian industrial legislation is a trial horse for the Howard-Reith industrial legislation that they would visit nationally on Australia should they, unfortunately, win elective office in this country. The business community, which has recognised and valued the industrial calm and harmony created by this government—a government which has emphasised cooperation in the work place, not confrontation—appreciates that we are now going through a time during which we are enjoying the lowest level of industrial disputation since the war and since the industrial dispute figures have been collected. They are worried about the intent of the opposition in this case. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Treasurer. Does the government support the 15 per cent across-the-board wage claim being pursued by the building workers union and supported by the ACTU President, Jennie George? How does the across-the-board nature of the claim assist in the development of enterprise bargaining? Why is the Masters Builders' Association wrong in claiming that the 15 per cent wage increase could lead to both increased inflationary pressures and the loss of 20,000 jobs on top of the 80,000 jobs it predicts will be shed as a result of the collapse of the home building industry and increasing difficulties in the commercial construction sector?

—I am not entirely sure that this is a question for the Treasurer. It seems more likely to be a question for the Minister representing the Minister for Industrial Relations, and it seems that the question should be appropriately directed to that minister, my colleague Senator Robert Ray. However, since the question has been asked of me, albeit erroneously and perhaps on a misunderstanding or simply from ignorance, let me go to the answer.

PARA.TAB: The government has set up an industrial relations system in Australia which has decentralised wage fixing from a highly centralised system to one which is enterprise based. In the context of enterprise bargaining in the building sector—or in any other sector—claims will be served which are ambit in nature and which will be supported by the unions and rejected by employers. One hopes in all of those cases that the two parties can get together to amicably negotiate an outcome to which they both feel bound, and productivity grows as a consequence.

Our industrial relations reform has been achieved without any major hiccup in the industrial relations environment and without any significant lost time because of a transition from one model to another model—from centralised to decentralised bargaining. That is not to say that there will not be disputes at the time enterprise bargains are struck. Both the coalition model, to the extent we know anything at all about it, and our model recognise the inevitability of that.

It is not for me to judge the validity or otherwise of individual claims in industry. It is for the parties in that industry to work that out and to find a basis for exchanging productivity growth for wage increases. Our model, which has lowered industrial disputation in Australia, has also worked to grow labour productivity to historically high levels in this country and to high levels according to OECD standards.

I do not accept Senator Parer's invitation. I am not familiar with the arguments in this individual case and I am not the appropriate minister on this occasion. I do not accept the opposition's arguments and I will not go to the individual case. It is for the parties to work that out and for the parties to feel bound by the outcome.

What we do know is that the opposition is incubating an industrial relations policy which, if the opposition were elected to government, would be provocative and would end the period of industrial harmony which this nation has enjoyed and promote industrial disputation.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I raise a point of order. I think you realise that we have exhibited a fair degree of patience, but the relevance of this answer to the question I asked is in question.
—I have ruled many times on these sorts of things. If a question is asked in a fairly general way about a general issue, I am not in a position to tell the minister how to answer it.

—The one thing that the opposition can do to get rid of that tag—and there is one thing that it can do—is to accept the government's position in terms of an industrial safety net so that workers cannot be exploited on a range of conditions. The opposition says it has a safety net in place. It is a very narrow safety net. If you were a trapeze artist, it would be like trying to fall onto a tightrope. Our safety net is a very broad one which protects real workers, and their real interests, and enables them to bargain with some dignity with their employers. If the opposition wants to escape the perception of the Australian people about its policies, one of the things it has to do is adopt our principles in terms of award protection and worker protection by having a dinkum safety net to protect individual workers.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. The question to the Minister representing the Treasurer is this: why is the Master Builders' Association wrong in claiming that a 15 per cent across-the-board wage increase being promoted by his union and the ACTU President Jennie George will lead to both increased inflationary pressures and the loss of 20,000 jobs? I also ask how the minister, in his response, can correlate an across-the-board increase with so-called productivity increases required by enterprise bargaining agreements.

—I have already said that I am the wrong minister to ask these questions of. And, once again, I am the wrong minister to ask these questions of because I do not come here with a brief from the Minister for Industrial Relations. If you want to ask him those questions, ask him. But I suspect that he would say something like this: unlike the coalition, we as government are not going to insert ourselves in every industrial dispute between the parties, and we are not going to judge the competing arguments that the parties put forward. What we are going to do is create a framework for the parties to negotiate successfully, basically on the grounds of growing productivity to fund wage increases, and do so without taking sides in that in order that the outcome of those negotiations can be the property of both parties, affirmed by them and therefore supported and carried through by them. That is our policy. We do not want to put the government in every workplace in Australia, like you do.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs. Yesterday on Channel 10's Meet the Press program the opposition's environment spokesman, Senator Rod Kemp, accused the government of using the external affairs power as a `constitutional battering ram'. What is the government's approach to the use of international treaties to protect the environment?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The government remains committed to active participation in the negotiation and implementation of international treaties which deal with environmental issues of global dimensions. It is well known that that is our position. We make no bones about it. There is no equivocation, there is no fumbling, there is no mumbling, and there is no stumbling of the kind that poor old Elmer subjected us to in his performance yesterday morning.

PARA.TAB: Whether the coalition likes it or not—and obviously it doesn't very much—the need for international cooperation on the environment is increasing rather than diminishing. And this government does take its responsibility as a good international citizen seriously. We also take very seriously our responsibility to protect the environment, using such constitutional mechanisms as are reasonably available to us. The difficulty about the opposition is that it is caught in a time warp between, on the one hand, the hairy-chested posturing to those it has tried to convince that the government is misusing the external affairs power and, on the other hand, the green constituency that it is belatedly—and now incompetently—trying to woo.

Yesterday Senator Kemp was asked whether he could provide just one example of where the government had improperly used its external affairs power. Back-pedalling furiously, we had Senator Kemp saying:

ANSWER.PARA: Well, I think the particular debate has moved on and I think the Government is pulling back from the position it had in the `80s . . .
Either he couldn't or he wouldn't produce a single example of where the Commonwealth had misused or inappropriately used the external affairs power.

PARA.TAB: So let us look at where we did use the external affairs power during the 1980s when he said that it was misconceived. The facts are that it was used by us in a way that the opposition hated then and continues to hate now to protect the Franklin River, to stop logging in the Wet Tropics, to stop the building of the Quaid Road, just north of Cairns, and to stop logging in the Lemonthyme and the southern forests of Tasmania. I ask the opposition: which of those uses of the external affairs power in the 1980s was inappropriate? Which was inappropriate then? Which would be inappropriate now? Senator Kemp did not tell us, and he cannot tell us.

Moreover, the government has much more recently used the external affairs power at Hinchinbrook to prevent the Great Barrier Reef from an inappropriate development which we all know about. Senator Kemp was asked his views about this. He simply did not know what to say. He stumbled and fumbled, and he said that the use of powers came under an act of parliament. Of course it came under an act of parliament. One would have thought that after eight months in the job he would have worked out that the act which was used, the act of parliament which was at issue here to protect the Great Barrier Reef, was exactly the same act of parliament enacted in reliance on the external affairs power that was used to save the Franklin and the rainforests of North Queensland.

The point about that act of parliament was not that it was an act of parliament but that it was an act of parliament built in reliance on the external affairs power. It was an act to implement the World Heritage Convention. It was introduced by the Labor government in 1983, and we remain very proud indeed of that particular piece of legislation and never make any apology for it.

The coalition's position on the use of the external affairs power has not changed at all. The coalition has consistently been critical, in general terms, of the Commonwealth's use of the external affairs power. The alternative that it offers is, as a result, a Tasmanian wilderness that is dammed, world heritage rainforests that are logged and a Kakadu National Park that is mined.

The particular issue, finally, of forests is one on which the opposition was left conspicuously stumbling yesterday. Senator Kemp was asked what he thought the opposition's view was on the government's endeavour to protect additional forests. The government, of course, supports the world-class 15 per cent reserve criteria. The opposition did not answer the question: does it support that 15 per cent criteria? Does it support the much weaker 10 per cent criteria proposed by the Liberal state government? You did not tell us yesterday. You cannot tell us. You made a goose of yourself. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Employment, Education and Training. Youth unemployment has reached an appalling rate of 29 per cent and has actually increased one per cent from 28.1 per cent since Working Nation commenced 16 months ago with the promise that the youth training initiative would have a very significant impact on youth unemployment. If one-third of all unemployed Australians have been unemployed for longer than one year and youth unemployment is rising prior to the end of year school leavers coming onto the job market, what hope can your tired, out-of-touch government give to the 60,000 young people still out of work after one year? Aren't our young people right to be despondent about their future because of the direction in which your government has taken this country?
—It is quite clear that this question is a tired old re-run of Mr Kemp's press statement of last week about youth unemployment.
—Dr Kemp to you.

—Dr Kemp, then. I just want to point out to Senator Campbell: the most recent ABS data indicates that, over the year to October 1995, the teenage unemployment rate increased in seasonally adjusted terms from 28.3 per cent to 29 per cent, and the number of full-time unemployed teenagers showed a slight increase of 200 to 95,600. Over the year to September 1995, however, the latest ABS data shows that, in original terms, the unemployment rate of the 20- to 24-year-old group fell from 12.6 per cent to 11.6 per cent.

PARA.TAB: The government acknowledges, of course, that youth unemployment continues to be a serious problem. It has introduced a range of measures, including Austudy, Working Nation's youth training initiative, and the recently announced jobs pathway guarantee program. These initiatives are delivering more opportunities than ever before for young people to participate in education and training which will, of course, lead to full-time employment.

I want to point out to the opposition that the training initiative and the Working Nation initiatives, which over a four-year period run into several billion dollars of expenditure, are aimed at improving particularly the opportunities for young people to get training and to get jobs through the subsidy schemes to employers. If you care to go and talk to a range of employers around Australia, like those of us in the government have been doing, you will find they are very well received.

The point I would make to the opposition is: you consistently attack the Working Nation initiatives and the expenditure on providing this training. But we have not had one skerrick of information from the opposition. If you are so critical of Working Nation and those initiatives, what would you do instead? The last time we heard anything from the opposition about youth unemployment—and it has never been commented further upon, revoked or whatever—was the suggestion that the youth wage in Australia should be reduced to $3 per hour. That is the last time you people made a comment about policy objectives for youth unemployment. That was over three years ago. Since then, you have been utterly silent. So it is extraordinary hypocrisy for you to come in here and weep crocodile tears about youth unemployment when you do nothing but attack the Working Nation initiatives.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I raise a point of order. My question asked the minister why his government's policies are making youth unemployment go up when they promised Working Nation would make it go down. It was not asking him questions about our policies. The fact is that the coalition has already released detailed policies on youth unemployment and employment programs and repudiated the $3 youth wage time after time. So, Minister, do not stand up in parliament and lie about our policies; get up and tell the truth about yours.
—Order! Get to your point of order.
—That is the point of order. It is could you direct the minister to answer the question about the failure of his government's policies.
—Order! I would ask you to withdraw that reference to a lie, too.
—Mr President, when he gets up and says—
—I ask you to withdraw that unconditionally, senator.
—I do so, Mr President. But I can say that the minister now has mislead the parliament in relation to that matter.
—There is no point of order. I call the minister.
—I have finished my answer, Mr President.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I ask the minister: if his Working Nation policies are so good, why is it that after 13 years of Labor government a youth survey conducted by the Australian Science and Technology Council, which he would be familiar with as the former minister for science until he lost that job, found that young Australians expect a poor quality of life and a `bad time of crisis and trouble' into the next century?

—Again, I would say to the opposition that we await you to announce some details of what you would do for youth unemployment. We accept, and I acknowledged in my answer, the seriousness of youth unemployment in Australia.
—What are you going to do about it?
—As I have pointed out before to the boofhead, Senator Ian Macdonald, who consistently interjects, we announced in Working Nation in May of last year the most expansive program—

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: Establishment of Film Studio in Sydney

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for Communications and the Arts. Will any government appropriation for the proposed Fox studio in Sydney be paid to News Corporation or any other company associated with the studio proposal either directly or through the New South Wales government? How many jobs in the Australian entertainment industry will be created by this proposed expenditure? Can the government guarantee that the studio will produce quality Australian programs rather than cheap international films with little connection with Australia? Has the government taken any steps to ensure that the Fox foreign investment will be of net economic benefit to Australia and that the profits from this government sponsored project stay in Australia?

—The appropriation bills make clear that the $7 million—that is the initial appropriation—will be paid to the New South Wales government, not to the News Corporation. Its use is for purposes to do with expenditures on infrastructure, et cetera, with regard to it.
—What does that mean?
—I can give you more detail but that was not the question. To the best of my knowledge none of it will be paid to News Corporation. I am certain none of it will be paid directly. That is quite clear.
—That's a relief.

—It was never in any doubt. If you had not been trying to mislead people, no-one would be in any doubt. But it has never been in any doubt, Senator Bourne. If there is any possibility of indirect payment I will get some information to you about that. But my understanding is that it is going to be spent directly on the infrastructure elements and that has been made public on several occasions before now.

PARA.TAB: With regard to jobs, the New South Wales government advice has been that the film studio facility at full operation could generate up to 750 jobs directly, an additional 865 jobs indirectly and $85 million in production expenditure.

With regard to the films that will be produced there, the government in fact welcomes Fox studio's announcement to build an Australian world-class film and television production facility at the showgrounds. My understanding is that it is intended to be a focus for the Australian production industry and, therefore, should help enhance Australia's reputation in film making and allow our indigenous industry and professionals to compete internationally.

Fox has not given a precise figure—and I do not think it could as yet—on the proportion of local production which will be undertaken. It has given a guarantee of its commitment to the Australian industry. The CEO of Fox studios said that he envisaged between 20 per cent to 40 per cent of the production being Fox production—some local, some international—with the balance being undertaken by independent producers.

With regard to your question concerning the net economic benefit, the project is expected to generate two kinds of benefit. Firstly, as I understand it, rent of at least $2 million per annum will be paid. Secondly, as I identified earlier in answer to your question, there will be the generation of 615 jobs directly or indirectly, and that is not a bad start. It has been estimated that the direct benefit to the economy of New South Wales is expected to be about $212 million per annum after five years of operation.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the minister for his comprehensive answer, but there are two extra points that come out of it. First of all, does this complement or contradict the better cities program, which the government has been pushing, in relation to the impact it will have on people who live around the development? Also, in that same vein, is there a proposed EIS that would look into the environmental impact and also the social impact on people living around the studio?

—Expenditure to defray costs for site preparation, infrastructure development and precinct planning, et cetera, does not seem to me to be inconsistent with better cities. I have not heard any concern expressed that that would be the case. That anybody would be concerned about the generation of jobs in Sydney does not seem to me to be a serious concern.

PARA.TAB: With regard to the EIS, the Minister for Communications and the Arts is responsible for decisions regarding designation of the Sydney showgrounds site under the Environmental Protection (Impact of Proposals) Act. If he decides to designate the activity, it will then be referred to the Commonwealth Environmental Protection Authority for consideration of what level of environmental impact assessment, if any, is required.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: Royal Australian Air Force: South Pacific Forum

How many RAAF Hercules flew into Madang in connection with or in support of the South Pacific Forum and the Prime Minister's visit to PNG in September? Senator Newman refers to an article by Ms Fia Cumming, which had all the hallmarks of such a story. The essence of the story was that a special flight was put on. That is not true. It was a regularly scheduled training flight. I say that in the full confidence—
—The oldest one in the book!

—You are absolutely right. It had to be checked, Senator Alston, because I am a bit too old and cunning to fall for that one. But I did check today to make sure that it was a scheduled training flight, scheduled long before the desire to move any equipment at all. For once, it turns out that it was a regularly scheduled training flight.

PARA.TAB: How many flights would have gone there depends on the circumstances. I do not know in this case; I will certainly get you that information. But it is not unusual not only to operate on an opportunity basis but to actually put on a flight like that to carry equipment to south-west Pacific countries. I am not sure whether that happened on this occasion.

TALK.START.PARA: —How many did it take?

—I will get that information for you. What this does show us is the trivia that the opposition is emersed in, especially the aspirant to the deputy prime ministership. Wearing funny hats and getting onto every cheap, opportunistic, crass, populist issue—

—I raise a point of order. I asked the minister for some very specific detail which he quite surprisingly is not in possession of. I would have expected him to be fully briefed after that article yesterday. He has now said all that he can possibly say. He is attempting to chatter on about the opposition so as to take some cheap political points when he has been revealed as not being prepared today for question time on a matter which relates to the expenditure of taxpayers' funds. —There is no point of order. The minister has a right to expand on the points that he has already made.
—I will bring myself very relevantly back to the point that Senator Newman has made and then I will divert off, if I like.
—No, you will not.

—Yes, I will. Senator Newman asked me a question on the basis of a story about a particular flight. I told her that it was a regular training flight. She also asked me whether there were any other flights. She asked me to table that. That I do not know and that is information I have promised to get her. What I am pointing out is the trivial nature of this matter brought up by a very trivial individual. I am not talking about her: I am talking about Mr Tim Fischer, the current Leader of the National Party of Australia and someone who aspires to be Deputy Prime Minister of this country.

—I rise on a point of order. Mr President, I draw your attention to standing order 193 which, as you obviously know, precludes Senator Ray from making disparaging remarks against any other member of any other house of parliament. I ask you to call him to order and tell him he is not allowed to make those remarks under that standing order.
—Order! The senator is correct. The remark does reflect on a person in another place and I would ask you, Senator Ray, not to do that.

—Let me reflect in this way: I regard Mr Tim Fischer as a very nice person. I regard a lot of my neighbours as very nice people, but I do not want them to be Deputy Prime Minister. TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister for Industry, Science and Technology. What exactly are the benefits to workers of the micro-economic reforms involving the privatisation of utilities such as electricity and power, water, sewerage and airports? Mr John Prescott of BHP was quoted in the Financial Review of 6 November as saying that `higher utility costs for essential services feed into wage claims'. You were quoted in the same paper on 8 November as saying that some states were privatising utilities `for return to their budget bottom line, rather than finding greater efficiencies'. Why should workers trying to raise families support micro-economic reform or show wage restraint when they see little benefits or reduced utility bills? Who, besides privatised utility companies and governments, are benefiting from this type of micro-economic reform? (Time expired)

—I start with the quote that Senator Harradine has correctly fed back to me. The point I was making is that, for example, the Western Australian government would argue that it is contributing to micro-economic reform by its labour market deregulation, yet we all know that the provocative nature of that labour market deregulation has in fact created anxiety for workers, led to industrial disputation, broken down Australia's industrial harmony, created bad figures on strikes per 1,000 employees in Australia and shaken business confidence in Australia. I do not believe that that is micro-economic reform. Nonetheless, some conservative governments trumpet around Australia that things that they do that follow their own ideological bent are micro-economic reform. They give micro-economic reform a bad name.

PARA.TAB: What this government is concerned about—I think this comes close to what Senator Harradine was referring to—is the Hilmer report into competition policy. We and the states jointly sponsored that report. It finds that a range of initiatives should be taken at Commonwealth and state level to introduce competition to public sector monopolies in order that, through competition, the price of the service delivered by those public sector monopolies is reduced and efficiencies are found to do that.

Obviously, this has to be seen in the context of the overall reform agenda of the Australian government. We have opened up the Australian economy and reduced tariff protection at a speed and in a way that has not burned off Australian industry—we have allowed it to face international competition and grow stronger—and we are now exporting many more manufactured goods, particularly higher value added manufactured goods, than ever before. That is a positive response to the opening up of the economy. But, if only the trade exposed sector of the economy bears the brunt of reform and you do not reform the non-trade exposed area of the economy, in the end Australia will lose its competitive edge and Australian companies in the trade exposed sector will be overwhelmed by international competition. Therefore, our thrust as government has been to push for opening up the economy, internationalising it through tariff change and the removal of non-tariff barriers, while at the same time engaging in a bold program of micro-economic reform. In this context I mean true reform and not the sorts of ideological things given the name of reform that some state governments wish to pursue. I would not describe as classic micro-economic reform what a number of state governments do; it is not aimed at finding greater efficiencies.

When efficiencies are found, input costs to business are cheaper, the level of competitiveness of those businesses grows, our share of the international economy grows and jobs are created in Australia. That is what I regard as reform. But, when you do a number of things simply for the sake of returning funds to your bottom line without necessarily improving efficiency, I do not regard that as reform.

One of the other classics, and one that I have talked about in this chamber fairly frequently, is the decision of the South Australian government to outsource the state's water management facilities and not allow a single Australian company to bid for the management of that process. It has excluded Australian owned companies and allowed only foreign owned companies to bid. I do not regard that as micro-economic reform in the true sense either.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I happen to agree with the minister that the Western Australian government's amendments to the industrial relations legislation are certainly not micro-economic reform in the true sense. But from your response can I take it that what you are really saying is that the micro-economic reform involving the privatisation of utilities that I have mentioned has not benefited workers? How has it benefited workers, particularly workers with families? Their power bills are going up. It is a user pays situation. They are going to be charged extra for landing taxes and the like. Can you describe how people are likely to benefit, because I believe that you are admitting that they will not benefit.
—The utilities you are referring to are in the main state utilities. Our reform agenda is about—
—And the airports.

—The airports will generate further ongoing capital investment in the airport industry—particularly the Badgerys Creek airport—and open up the gateway to New South Wales. That is a very positive change. The essential principle I am getting at is that, if you create greater efficiencies and reduce input costs to private sector business, you reduce their costs and increase their ability to compete in the international market. That creates jobs for Australians. That is the sort of reform that we are about. Some of the states are more concerned about things other than that—and where they are, I have criticised them. What are the advantages to workers? If they have cheaper electricity, cheaper water and cheaper everything else, it is an advantage to their living standards. (Time expired)

—My question is directed to the Minister for Small Business, Customs and Construction. This morning's AAP wire contained a story from Osaka based on the APEC customs symposium held there last week. The claims in the wire would indicate that the area of customs is quietly emerging as one of the untold success stories of APEC. Do you support these claims? If so, what role has Australia played in this process?

—Yes, I can support very strongly those claims and that story. I acknowledge that last week the Chief Executive of Australian Customs, Lionel Woodward, was keynote speaker at the Osaka symposium. Australian Customs was the only APEC member customs administration asked to present a keynote address, which reflects the ongoing leadership Australian Customs has given in this area, going right back to 1993 when it was chair of the APEC customs procedures group. We have played a very significant leadership role.

PARA.TAB: Australian Customs was a key player in the customs procedures subcommittee chaired by Japan this year and will maintain that level of support when the Philippines becomes the chair in 1996. The program put forward an ambitious and forward-looking nine-point action plan which includes specific deadlines and benchmarks which were agreed to earlier this year.

The nine-point action plan agreed to by APEC customs administrations covers a number of items. I will not go into them all, but they range from implementation of international conventions, such as the GATT valuation code and intellectual property rights by the year 2000, to revising an international harmonised system for tariff classification by 1998 and adherence to the UN/EDIFACT international electronic message standards by the year 1999. I know that they may sound rather boring and complicated names, but this is the real meat of what we are developing to encourage free trade in the APEC region—the harmonisation of customs procedures.

These goals are not unrealistic and they indicate a common commitment by all APEC customs administrations to modernisation and harmonisation of procedures in order to facilitate free trade. Australian Customs has already agreed to implement this action plan and has achieved great progress in simplifying and modernising its procedures. At present in Australia 98 per cent of all cargo coming into and going out of the country is being processed electronically with no lessening of Customs' border protection obligations. The vast majority is immediately released on arrival with no further processing required.

I give the Senate another practical example. In discussions with Qantas and the Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs we have introduced the advanced passenger clearance process which will reduce by about half the time that passenger processing takes place at airports. Discussions are now under way with other airlines of the APEC economies to see whether they will also adopt this new technique.

Customs has been at the forefront. The leadership provided by Customs staff has been excellent. We anticipate that at the Osaka leaders meeting we will see a number of decisions taken by the leaders which will further enhance the development of free trade by the adoption of these procedures in customs harmonisation.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question to the Minister for Defence concerns the military use of Nomad aircraft. The minister will be aware that Australian Defence Force Nomads were grounded in September 1994 due to airworthiness limitations relating to their military use. A decision to dispose of the aircraft has since been made. Would the minister please confirm and explain why a civilian Nomad aircraft was chartered for army parachute training in August 1995? Why were Australian soldiers subjected to a risk deemed to be unsafe by the government's own decision?

—One thing does not necessarily follow another even though all the facts mentioned by Senator Macdonald are correct. The decision to ground the Nomads a year ago was due to a particular mechanical problem that had to be rectified in Nomads throughout the world. The decision to no longer use them was made on three bases: firstly, the cost of using them in the fleet; secondly, utility; and thirdly, the necessity to fly a plane within an envelope for safety reasons.

PARA.TAB: My presumption is that the hiring of a civilian Nomad was still within the envelope in which the Nomads are quite useful. Taking the absolute coverage of what we require of such a fixed-wing plane, its utility is no longer there. That is not to say that the plane per se is bad. It is not to say that the plane's safety record is necessarily worse than many other equivalent planes. A lot of the figures have been done.

TALK.START.PARA: —Particularly for civilian use.

—Yes, I acknowledge that: for civilian use and, if I could add, for certain military tasks for which some of our neighbouring countries use them. They fly in a much narrower envelope with a much narrower requirement than we require. I imagine that would be the reason why it was hired on that particular occasion. We hire a number of fixed-wing planes to do the job that military Nomads once did, and we will continue to do so. What I will do for you, though, is check to make sure that the method of using that particular civilian Nomad in no way trespassed the envelope in which they were required to fly. If they did, that would be a serious allegation and one that I would take very seriously. But I do not think that is the case.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy. The Australian Democrats are very concerned about the papaya fruit fly crisis in North Queensland. We have heard from a number of sources that the department of primary industry in Queensland, with the full knowledge of the National Registration Authority, was seriously considering aerial and ground spraying, using organophosphate chemicals to saturation point, of North Queensland rainforests, some of which are in the wet tropics world heritage area. I understand that since last Thursday it has changed this strategy for the moment to an aerial baiting program. I ask the minister: was there ever a serious consideration given to spraying organophosphates into rainforests in North Queensland? Can the minister give an unequivocal assurance to this parliament that there will be no spraying of chemicals, aerially or from the ground, on North Queensland rainforests?

—When the technical experts were looking at all of the options that were technically available in terms of treating the fly—and some of those options came to me—one of those options, which in fact was at the top of the list, was the aerial spraying of malathion. I can assure the Senate that I actually blinked a bit when I saw that recommendation at the top of the list, but it was only canvassing all of the possibilities and options which needed to be canvassed to deal with the fly.

PARA.TAB: I would have had very grave concerns about the aerial spraying of malathion not just over the rainforest but also over the suburbs of Cairns and various other places. Even though it is obviously, from a technical quarantine perspective, an option that had to be considered, it was also an option that I rejected in about 10 seconds. I can assure you that that is currently not under consideration, nor is it likely to be.

But I do wish to tell you that there would have been, in terms of the source of your stories, some validity to it at least in that it was a technical option. In my view it would never have proceeded at all. There has been considerable success overseas with the suppression and eradication of this particular fly by using a bait which is in fact very safe. It is a sexual attractant bait which attracts the male flies. After they are attracted in pursuit of the sex bait, they die in the attempt.

TALK.START.PARA: —Have you tested it, Bob?
—It is only human, isn't it. I am told these are very effective in breaking the breeding cycle of the papaya fruit fly, as with other fruit flies.
—We won't need males at all, soon.
—You will be interested to know that the technique is called the methyl eugenol male annihilation technique. I am assured it does not work on people.

PARA.TAB: For the senator's information, bait spraying and the methyl eugenol male annihilation strategy will commence this week in Mossman, Mareeba and outlying infestations to suppress the suspected breeding populations prior to the wet season. During this initial phase, intensive information gathering on the spread of the fly will proceed to assist decisions on whether a full-scale eradication program will be feasible. I expect that a decision on whether a full-scale eradication program will be feasible will be available around mid-December after technical, economic, environmental and public health issues are considered. But I can assure the Senate that aerial spraying of malathion anywhere—over rainforests or anywhere else—is not being considered.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask that further questions be placed on the Notice Paper.

—Further to an answer I gave Senator Sandy Macdonald about hepatitis C and Interferon, I have some information for the senator. The Commonwealth is committed to providing funding to meet the drug costs of Interferon for the treatment of hepatitis C outpatients of public hospitals in all states and territories. Comprehensive details of nominated treatment centres may be obtained from state and territory health departments.Section 100 of the National Health Act provides for the Commonwealth to make grant payments to states and territories for the provision of highly specialised drugs for community based hospital patients. Interferon is one such drug subsidised under these arrangements since 1 October 1994.

PARA.TAB: While the government will meet the drug costs for eligible patients on the program, the decision to provide therapy and other associated services is the responsibility of the state and territory governments. The provision of services and drugs for hospital in-patients is the responsibility of the state and territory governments. Although the relatively recent availability of Interferon treatment has placed pressures on some specialist hospital clinics, the location of treatment centres and the prioritisation of patient waiting lists for Interferon treatment are issues for state and territory governments.

At the same time, it is understood that some patients may be referred inappropriately early to these specialist services because some general practitioners are uncertain of how to treat hepatitis C. In response, the NHMRC is currently developing appropriate and accurate laboratory, clinical and treatment guidelines, particularly targeting GPs who have an important ongoing role in the management of people with hepatitis C. It is anticipated that these guidelines will shortly be available for a second stage public consultation.

It should be noted that the provision of treatment with Interferon is only part of a public health response to hepatitis C, and the Commonwealth has been progressing a range of activities under the national hepatitis C action plan such as improved education and surveillance, as noted in my original answer to the senator's question.
