—It is with deep regret that I inform the Senate of the death, on 4 November 1995, of Yitzhak Rabin, Prime Minister of Israel.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALKER.NAME: Senator GARETH EVANS
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Government in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate—

SPEECH.PARA: (1)expresses its deep regret at the death, on 4 November 1995, of Mr Yitzhak Rabin, Prime Minister of Israel,
(2)condemns the brutal act which took his life,
(3)tenders its profound sympathy to his widow, Mrs Leah Rabin, the members of his family and to the Government and people of Israel in their bereavement,
(4)urges all Israelis to respond to this outrage by strengthening their commitment to the peace process, and
(5)requests that this motion be conveyed by the President on behalf of the Senate to the Government of Israel.

We can never directly experience the pain felt by Israelis and by Diaspora Jews at the terrible assassination of Yitzhak Rabin, but we can at least endeavour to share some of that pain and take this first parliamentary occasion to offer our compassion.

PARA.TAB: Prime Minister Rabin was a true Israeli. Born in Jerusalem in 1922, he was a man of great courage, great capacity, great tenacity, and of course great patriotism. As Acting Prime Minister, Kim Beazley, put it so well during his contribution to the memorial service held at the Melbourne Hebrew Congregation last week:

Every event which has marked the history of Israel had Yitzhak Rabin at its core. Even as a young man after the war of 1948, he was involved in negotiations separating the forces, as well as having been involved in the fighting. He was a hero in every major event in Israel's survival thereafter. His life as a warrior, diplomat, politician and statesman was of a piece . . . Every step, every direction, he held before him a devotion to his nation, its survival, its health and the right of its citizens to live in peace.

SPEECH.PARA: Prime Minister Rabin's vision was for an Israel living free from conflict with its Arab neighbours. He well understood the force of that very wise statement by David Ben-Gurion back in the 1940s at the time of the foundation of Israel that the new country could be Jewish, it could be democratic and it could occupy the whole of the biblical land of Israel, but it could not be all three. Yitzhak Rabin recognised that peace on the principle of land for peace was the only way forward for Israel. He dedicated his political energies to advancing the peace process.

PARA.TAB: During his second term as Prime Minister from 1992, he did make an historic contribution—and it is now universally acknowledged—to the achievement of progress in the Middle East peace process, a contribution for which, with his colleague Shimon Peres and his negotiating partner, PLO Chairman Yasser Arafat, he was very appropriately awarded the Nobel Peace Prize.

Under his leadership, Israel and the Palestine Liberation Organisation reached agreement on a process for peace. He was instrumental in achieving the peace treaty between Israel and Jordan signed in October 1994. I do not think any of us will ever forget the original historic appearance at the White House on 13 September 1993 when he shook the hand of his former adversary, Yasser Arafat, in what was a deeply symbolic gesture of peace.

I had the pleasure of meeting Yitzhak Rabin on several occasions. While unquestionably a rather dour personality, I always found him quite engaging, not least because of the directness, the sincerity and the impressive commitment that just shone through him in his approach to the issues of the day. Perhaps the most revealing exchange I had with him was one that I have had occasion to recount publicly a couple of times in the last week, but I will do so again.

It was just in July this year that we had been talking about the current state of the Palestinian track of the peace process and, having just come from a meeting with Chairman Arafat in the Gaza, I was being so bold as to suggest that in a couple of specific respects Israel might perhaps find it possible to be a little more flexible in its negotiation. Then I stopped in midstream and said, `But of course on all of this I am preaching to the converted.'

There was a little pause during which a little half-smile played over Yitzhak Rabin's lips—I think I know what his granddaughter was saying when she referred to that half-smile in her own extraordinarily moving tribute to her grandfather at the funeral service a few days ago—and he said to me, `The committed, not the converted.' You are preaching to the committed, not to the converted.

There was a core, a residue, of absolute toughness about him, a determination to not let his heart rule his head in any way, shape or form but, at the same time, there was no doubt where his head was at. He was absolutely committed intellectually to the peace process and absolutely determined to make it work. That commitment was known, respected and indeed admired throughout the Middle East and also, I am sure, among some of the most hard-headed and hard-nosed of his opponents, or negotiating partners as it is perhaps preferable to call them.

Certainly, when I had a conversation with President Assad just a couple of days after that one, and felt moved to retail this little exchange to President Assad, he was enormously amused by it, representing and conveying as it did so much of the essence of Yitzhak Rabin the leader, and President Assad recognising very much a fellow hard nose in the Middle East peace process.

Because of the approach he adopted to the peace process, combining commitment with caution and certainly investing all his enormously hard won reputation as a defence leader and soldier, it was Yitzhak Rabin more than anyone else who advanced that peace process. Accordingly, his assassination is an immeasurable loss for Israel, for the Middle East and indeed for the whole world.

Israel was, of course, founded on the dream of Jewish people everywhere that Israel be a place of sanctuary; a place where people pay each other due regard and respect; a place where above all else human rights and human happiness were to be the foundations of the society. It was especially tragic in these circumstances that Yitzhak Rabin was killed, and killed by a fellow Jew, a fellow Israeli, because of his commitment to a peace process which was going to—and will, if it is carried through to fruition—ensure the safety and security of all Israelis better than any comparable approach to the country's security would ever be able to do.

The Prime Minister, Paul Keating, represented Australia and all Australians at the funeral of Mr Rabin. It was, as we all saw from the television coverage, a very moving ceremony in which Mr Rabin was honoured as a person and a leader who had made an enormous contribution to his country and the world. Our Prime Minister's presence was both to pay our respect to Mr Rabin's memory and our respect to his family. But it was also to demonstrate Australia's continuing commitment to the ongoing peace process which we all hope will be the true legacy of Mr Rabin to his country and to the world.

Australia has long supported the right of Israel to a secure and peaceful existence among its Arab neighbours in the context of a comprehensive regional settlement. We have added to that position of principle a practical commitment of applying, to the extent that we reasonably can, Australian resources, skills and support in what is still a very vulnerable peace process. We have been part of the multilateral arms control and regional security track of the peace process and in that capacity have played an active role in trying to establish regional security centres in the Middle East to help promote confidence building measures and to enhance conflict prevention arrangements.

We have also been involved in another track of the multilateral process to do with water resources, in which capacity we have hosted discussions in Australia among Arab, Israeli and Australian water experts, seeking to address what obviously remains one of the most critical long-term threats to the political stability of the region as well as one of the most important elements of its future economic prosperity: water resources.

Another small contribution of ours to peace building is through a program of exchanges involving Israeli, Arab and Australian artists. These are modest contributions, and I do not pretend otherwise; but we do want to make a contribution to the Middle East peace process. We do want to make a contribution to Yitzhak Rabin's vision of a Middle East blessed by peace and prosperity, and we will continue to do what we can in support of peace in the Middle East.

As everyone is now saying—including, mercifully, an overwhelming majority of Israelis—such a lasting, just and comprehensive peace will be far and away the most appropriate tribute to Yitzhak Rabin's memory.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before calling Senator Hill, I draw the attention of honourable senators to the presence in the President's gallery of His Excellency Ambassador Moyal and Counsellor Aviran from the Israeli Embassy. I welcome you here.

PARA.TAB: Honourable senators—Hear, hear!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am pleased to associate the coalition with this motion of condolence. When Mr Rabin returned to office as Prime Minister in 1992, he said:

SPEECH.PARA: No longer are we necessarily a people that dwells alone, and no longer is it true that the whole world is against us. We must overcome the sense of isolation that has held us in its thrall for almost half a century. We must join the international movement towards peace, reconciliation and cooperation that is spreading over the entire globe these days—lest we be the last to remain, all alone, in that station.
Clearly, Mr Rabin committed himself to that goal, and in the end he sacrificed his life to that objective.

PARA.TAB: Today we are remembering not only a man who was a national hero to his people but a man who will be remembered as an international hero. The assassination was obviously a tragic event along the path to peace, which has been a very difficult path in the Middle East. It demonstrates just how rocky the road to peace is. It is a tragic event for his family, for all Israelis, for all Jewish people and for all people internationally who wish to see peace and stability in the Middle East. He will be remembered by all those people—and I put myself within that category—as an international hero.

Even the symbolism that was attached to his funeral demonstrated the changing environment and the legacy of his contribution to that path towards peace. The fact that President Mubarak of Egypt and King Hussein of Jordan would speak at his funeral and recommit themselves to that goal gives us confidence in the determination of many to ensure that his life was not given in vain. Similarly, I would associate with that the very moving comments of the Palestinian leader, Yasser Arafat, at the time when Mr Rabin's death was announced.

Even at the time of his funeral there were hopeful signs that the commitment Mr Rabin had given to the goal of peace would continue to be taken up by those with power and influence within the region. Additionally, the efforts in Israel that have flowed from the event of his assassination to root out intolerance and extremism, to ensure that a commitment to peace comes from within a state and not just between states, give us some hope that his work will be continued towards an ultimate positive end.

It is not easy in a region such as the Middle East to put hatred behind after such long periods of conflict. It really does take great leadership to be able to break through the barriers towards that goal. Mr Rabin brought to the people of Israel a confidence in progressing the peace process. He demonstrated it with the courage he took into negotiations between Israel and adjoining states when he was previously Prime Minister, as well as on this last occasion and, more recently, in the negotiations between Israel and the Palestinians.

The confidence he had in himself and the confidence that the people had in him came from his record as a warrior and a defender of Israeli and Jewish interests. That enabled him to communicate to the people that it is possible to achieve a peace with security. That had always been the great hindrance along the path to peace—with every step forward, there was the concern within Israel that security might be jeopardised by that last step.

Mr Rabin had the confidence of his people to be able to take the message that peace with security could be achieved. His people could step forward with confidence. It was a remarkable life. I will not repeat the details, but we have merely to consider his military career, his period as chief of state, his diplomatic service, his political contribution as defence minister and twice as Prime Minister, and his recognition by the international community as a Nobel Prize winner.

It is with sadness that we stand here today. Nevertheless, there is something moving about looking back upon a life that was so worth while in terms of not only his own people but the international community in general. I hope that Australia will honour the legacy of Mr Rabin by continuing to make a useful contribution towards the peace process in the Middle East. I was pleased to hear what Senator Evans said in that regard and I support his remarks. It is important that we, in our modest way, also demonstrate in a practical way that Mr Rabin has not given his life in vain. I take this opportunity to send the sincere sympathies of the coalition to Mr Rabin's wife and children.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Boswell Sen R.L.D.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOSWELL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to associate members of the National Party of Australia with the condolence motion moved by the government. The assassination of the former Israeli Prime Minister, Yitzhak Rabin, on 4 November shocked and saddened the world. It is an immense tragedy that the man who, after his election as Prime Minister in June 1992, the man who worked so hard to achieve peace in his region, should meet his untimely death at the hands of an Israeli extremist.

PARA.TAB: Yesterday, more than 250,000 mourners thronged the square in Tel Aviv where he met his death. His widow, Leah, bravely addressed the massed rally and called on the acting Prime Minister, Mr Peres, to continue to lead the people of Israel on the path to peace.

Born in Jerusalem in 1922 of Ukrainian parents who migrated to Palestine at the end of the First World War, Mr Rabin was for much of his life a career soldier. He undertook agricultural studies at workers' school but this was forgone as he embarked on his military career when he joined the Palmarch, an underground commando unit. Mr Rabin was a brigade commander during the Israeli war of independence in 1948. In 1963 he had risen to the most senior of military ranks when he became Israel's military chief of staff. Israel's victory in the six-day war against Egypt, Syria and Jordan was directly attributable to his military strategies and leadership.

In 1968 Mr Rabin was appointed Ambassador to the United States. When Golda Meir resigned as Prime Minister in 1974 Mr Rabin obtained the nomination of the governing Labour Party and won the election that year. During his first term as Prime Minister he instigated interim military agreements with Syria and Egypt, the precursor towards the binding Middle Eastern peace agreements he was to later construct.

In 1977 Mr Rabin was compelled to resign due to internal pressures, despite his successful authorisation of the commando raid that rescued 100 Israeli hostages from Entebbe airport the previous year. When he became Prime Minister for the second time in June 1992, at the age of 70, Mr Rabin was perfectly placed to lead his nation into the 21st century. He was a man whose formative life experiences were shaped by his military activities and a lifetime of working to build a securer Israel—yet at the same time was utterly committed to achieving peace in his region. In a speech to the Israeli parliament on 13 July 1992 Mr Rabin presented the vision of a peaceful Middle East:

SPEECH.PARA: In the last decade of the 20th century, walls of enmity have fallen, borders have disappeared, powers have crumbled, ideologies have collapsed.
We must join the international movement towards peace, reconciliation and cooperation that is spreading over the entire globe these days.

During his prime ministership, the landmark agreement between Israel and Palestine for Palestinian autonomy in the West Bank and the Gaza was hammered out. That was followed by a peace treaty with Jordan last year.

PARA.TAB: Mr Rabin was a great man who was absolutely instrumental in laying down the path of peace in the Middle East. The fact that peace in the Middle East was breaking out was demonstrated by the presence of King Hussein of Jordan at Mr Rabin's funeral and by the fact that Yasser Arafat paid a private condolence call to Mrs Rabin. It is the hope of the world community that the peace plan implemented by Mr Rabin is now so embedded in the psyche of the people of the Middle East that, despite the cruel efforts of a few extremists, this peace plan will not be unravelled.

Mr Rabin was the eighth Middle East leader to die at the hands of assassins in the past 20 years. Let there be no more. I am sure that all honourable senators will join with me in extending profound sympathy to both the family of Mr Rabin and the people of Israel in their time of great mourning.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kernot Sen C.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Australian Democrats I wish to associate us with the condolence motion before the Senate today and to make a few brief remarks. Some years ago Yitzhak Rabin said:

SPEECH.PARA: I had the opportunity to belong to this generation of Jewish people, to whom divine history leaves the chance to be masters of their own destiny.

In the years since he made this comment, Yitzhak Rabin almost certainly exceeded his own expectations of what he meant by these remarks by contributing to the sorts of diplomatic achievements that few world leaders ever imagine that they will be a part of.

PARA.TAB: History will undoubtedly record that the leadership shown by Yitzhak Rabin was instrumental in securing the peace process in the Middle East. In reaching out to Israel's traditional enemies, and more particularly to the Palestine Liberation Organisation and Mr Yasser Arafat, Mr Rabin went much further than anyone might have imagined possible. His vision and commitment to the peace process were all the more remarkable given his own background as a former army general. Yet it was probably because of this background as a military man and the credibility he had built up over the years on security issues that Yitzhak Rabin was able to convince so many of his fellow Israelis to follow his government down the road to peace.

If it is true that we are all remembered by our last action, Yitzhak Rabin will be remembered as a peacemaker. His efforts towards this goal—efforts which were overwhelmingly recognised by the international community and resulted in the awarding of the Nobel Peace Prize last year—and his endeavours towards peace were themselves nothing short of outstanding.

As others have said, the ultimate irony may be that, in giving his life, in his death he may well secure a lasting peace—but that is such an unnecessary price and probably very small comfort to his family. The onus now is for the rest of us to ensure that Yitzhak Rabin's efforts and tragic death were not in vain. The best way to ensure this, I think, is for the international community to do everything it can to ensure that a just and lasting peace is set in place in the Middle East and that this peace will survive any challenges that are thrown at it, including those that come from the extremist elements that unfortunately can fester in such circumstances.

So, in this regard, the Australian Democrats endorse the comments made both by the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) and by the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Senator Gareth Evans), who have on Australia's behalf expressed full support for a continuation of the peace process. There may be an opportunity for Australia to assist as Israel continues down the path to peace. We must consider all such requests if we are called upon to be involved or, if it is appropriate, for us to assist in any way.

In the week since Mr Rabin's tragic death so many words have been spoken and written about this great man. But I notice that others too have said that the words which moved us all were the words of his granddaughter. This remarkable young woman provided one of the most poignant impressions of the last few days when she delivered a very moving and intimate message to her grandfather—the grandfather she has just lost. Her message only sought to emphasise for me, and I am sure for most of us, the very personal impact which such tragedies have on the immediate family of leaders like Yitzhak Rabin who lead very public lives and who accept that responsibility.

Senator Vicki Bourne had the opportunity last week to represent the Democrats at the memorial service held in Sydney at the Great Synagogue. Senator Bourne asked me to repeat here the words of Rabbi Brian Fox, who at that service said:

SPEECH.PARA: We gather as human beings, praying to the God of Humanity.
We have a history of pain.
We all have our eyes full of tears.

But let our tears have meaning. Let our pain strengthen us to earnest resolve to love peace, shalom, salaam, and to work for peace . . . to embrace each other at each opportunity for building bridges of peace between each person created in the image of God.

On behalf of the Australian Democrats, I wholeheartedly endorse these comments and take this opportunity to also extend my party's sympathies to the Israeli government, the people of Israel and Yitzhak Rabin's family.

TALK.START.PARA: —This unnecessary death, this terrible tragedy, leads us today to this motion of condolence, which I know, Mr President, you will pass on to the ambassador of Israel and so to the people and nation of Israel and the family of Prime Minister Rabin. I join with all that the Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Gareth Evans) and the Leader of the Opposition (Senator Hill) have said here this afternoon. In addition, I wish to make three particular references.

PARA.TAB: I heard most keenly the reference that the widow of Prime Minister Rabin made to the environment for extremism, which is made possible if there is less than full responsibility by each member of the community in any nation and by the members of the opposition. If the spectrum of rhetoric gives any room for an evil act, it makes that evil act more possible. I do not know how to evaluate the environment of the rhetoric that the opposition, Likud, has contributed in Israel. I only hear the words of the widow, Mrs Rabin.

I know from experience that it is possible to build an environment—whether it is one party or another, one minority or another, by their own actions, speeches, words, policies—which makes extremist actions an evil all the more viable, all the more possible. One of the messages that comes to me from this terrible act is that we in all nations should give no room for extremism or for violence. Even when an opposition may have criticism of a government policy, including the peace process, they should be circumspect about not giving room for extremism and for violence.

Secondly, I wish to underline what is in this sad event a deterrent for extremists, for assassins. Let it be understood by any would-be assassin that in this event the consequence has been totally counterproductive to the attitude of the evil assassin. I judge there to be a single theme in the responses in the Senate today, in Australia, within Israel, amongst the Arab nations, in the UN, by the US President and by everyone who has responded: to therefore all the more reinforce the peace process and to ensure that the task and the goals to which Prime Minister Rabin was dedicated, including his last speech, be all the more assured, safeguarded and won.

I can only say realistically, after a week, that the assassin and anyone who has any support for that evil act can see that the action has been totally counterproductive. Let us hope that any extremists in any nation can pick up that message and realise that the fruits of violence are bitter and counterproductive.

Finally, I wish to refer to the peace process itself. Those senators who have visited my room—many of you have—particularly in the year following 25 September 1993, will have noticed that there was a photograph of Prime Minister Rabin, Chairman Arafat and President Clinton in the famous handshake which marked the conclusion of the peace process. Senators know that I have been involved through all my years in the Senate in foreign affairs matters. I regarded the end of the Cold War as one of the great victories of my time in this place. It has been contributed to from all over the world. The other great victory was this five-year peace process being launched by that famous handshake. All of us in this chamber metaphorically stood around Prime Minister Rabin and Chairman Arafat as they came together in this creative and unique way, a way that we welcomed.

I did not have the opportunity to meet former Prime Minister Rabin, but I did meet Chairman Arafat in the month after that handshake in the first discussions that Australian parliamentarians had been able to have with him. That was in Tunisia. In that month I was able to visit Egypt, Jordan, Syria and Lebanon and listen carefully so that we in the Australian parliament could respond as positively as possible in reinforcing the peace process. Since then I have always stood ready to visit Israel—a place which I have visited in the past and which I as one Australian parliamentarian would also want to encourage all the more in that peace process.

I welcome the statements of President Mubarak, King Hussein and Chairman Arafat, all recommitting themselves and their people to the peace process. Through you, Mr President, I extend to the ambassador and the representatives of Israel my own personal condolence to the family of Prime Minister Rabin and to the people and the nation of Israel. Our sadness is the same as that which we saw in the cutting down of President Sadat in Egypt. We wish to see an end to such death, we wish to see an end to such tragedy and we recommit ourselves to the peace process.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts Sen D.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Greens (WA) wish to join in supporting this motion today. The enormously difficult peace process in the Middle East is evidence that it is more than the absence of war. In speaking today, I wish to mention some quotes from Prime Minister Rabin in his own growing realisation of this fact. In the early 1990s Prime Minister Rabin became convinced that it was time for Israel to try in earnest to conclude a political settlement with its increasingly discontented Palestinian population and its Arab neighbours. This was in response to what was seen by many people as a world break-out of peace in areas which would never conceivably happen at the end of the Cold War. Prime Minister Rabin said:

SPEECH.PARA: In the last decade of the twentieth century, the atlases, history and geography books no longer present an up-to-date picture of the world. Walls of enmity have fallen, borders have disappeared. Powers have crumbled and ideologies collapsed, states have been born, states have died, and the gates of emigration have been flung open.

It was seen to be a concern that Israel not be left behind with the changing international climate. There are many facets to security which cannot be secured by guns or bombs. Ironically, as has been mentioned today, it was because of the trust that Yitzhak Rabin had gained in trying to defend Israel militarily that his people allowed him to explore non-military options towards peace.

PARA.TAB: Yitzhak Rabin was very aware of the need for an integrated approach to peace which realised that the mistrust and insecurity of neighbouring countries must be addressed at its source—the desire for a homeland, for an economic base, for self-determination and, of course, for peace. Unfortunately, it is all too easy for the peace between countries to be replaced by conflict within countries, especially as the new internationalism may help to accentuate the gap between rich and poor and associated differences in access to resources. Yitzhak Rabin's own statements in November 1993 recognise that there were many elements in creating peace. He recognised that there was a real need for self-determination in Palestine. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: For many years I served as a soldier. I believe that as a soldier I've seen not only victories of the armies, I've also seen the sufferings of the peoples of the countries in the region. And I believe that the time has arrived for the peoples and the leaders to find ways to change their way of thinking.
He also said:

We want the Palestinians to run the lives of the Palestinians in the territories. We would like to see a council, a self-governing authority, established in accordance to the DOP, by elections, and chosen by the Palestinians themselves.
Mr Rabin acknowledged the obstacles and the opposition to what he was doing. He said:
. . . there are forces that oppose the agreement in both the PLO and its leadership for signing the agreement as we in Israel have people who oppose the government and my decisions.

What he was doing was a very brave thing to do. The legacy of all peacemakers is to work towards building real security, an absence of fear, an equitable society which recognises that desperation can lead to desperate measures. I ask today that we should all work as peacemakers in our own region—to recognise the need for real and lasting security and, as Prime Minister Rabin has done, to build peace and maintain it as a precious gift. The Greens WA join the Senate in supporting this motion.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Short Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I too want to associate myself with the motion of condolence moved by the Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Gareth Evans) and with the words of my leader in the Senate, Senator Hill, and others on the tragic and senseless assassination of Yitzhak Rabin. He was in every sense of the word an extraordinary and leading world figure. He was the first sabra—Israeli-born—Prime Minister of Israel and he was also, in his first stint as Prime Minister in 1974, when elected to that position, the youngest Prime Minister that Israel has had.

PARA.TAB: Throughout many of his 73 years, Yitzhak Rabin was at the centre of nearly every major event in his nation's history, and collectively it was in a whole range of areas. For much of his career, he was a military figure and a military leader. He was also a diplomat, being the Israeli Ambassador to the United States for five years. His political life stretched over more than 20 years as a member of the Knesset. He was elected to the Knesset in December 1973 and became Prime Minister for the first time four or five months later than that—I think in April 1974.

He was also the defence minister for almost seven years, during which time many advances towards peace were made and the security of Israel's defence situation was reached. He capped a distinguished career as a peacemaker, in terms of the recognition of it, with the award of the Nobel Peace Prize in 1994. That was seen throughout the world as recognition which was extremely well deserved. He worked for many years to achieve peace in the Middle East, to bring a closer relationship and understanding between Israel and its Middle East neighbours. Very importantly, it was his efforts and that of others—Yasser Arafat and his colleague Shimon Peres—that led to the 1993 accord with the PLO on Palestinian self-rule in the West Bank. That was followed by a long series of negotiations with other Israeli neighbours, culminating in the peace treaty between Israel and Jordan just 12 months ago, in October 1994. Since then, there have been further developments along the path of the peace process. There is still a long way to go. But due to his efforts, very importantly, that peace process has proceeded down the path towards eventual success.

It is ironic that he was assassinated following a major peace rally at which he made a very successful address. I want to quote some of Prime Minister Rabin's words to that rally, because I think they sum up many of the reasons why the world so mourns his passing and why we feel such a grievous sense of loss. At that rally on 4 November, just minutes before he was assassinated, amongst other things Yitzhak Rabin said:
This Government, which I have the honour to lead with my friend Shimon Peres, has given peace a chance, a peace which will resolve most of the problems of the State of Israel.

For 27 years, I was a man of war, I fought for so long that I thought that there was no alternative. But today I believe that chance exists. A great occasion which we have to seize for those who are here and those who did not come.

And you who have come to this demonstration and those who have not come but support us, you prove that the people want peace and are against violence, because it is violence which undermines the foundations of the Israeli democracy.
We have to denounce it, we have to spit it out, we have to isolate it. It is not the way of democracies. We act according to a mandate we have been given.
I am proud to announce to you that at my sides are representatives from the countries with which we have made peace: Egypt, Jordan, Morocco.

As we once took up our role in war, we must now work to find a solution to the most complex issue of the Israeli-Arab conflict, the Israeli-Palestinians conflict. It is not easy, it is painful, but there is no alternative.
The path of peace is preferable to the path of war, this is a soldier telling you this, a defence minister, a man who sees the pain of the families of soldiers in mourning.

SPEECH.PARA: To me, no other words could better express the road on which Prime Minister Rabin had moved—the road to peace which he held so dear and, indeed, for which he gave his life. He was a great statesman. He was a great and courageous leader of the Israeli people. His loss will be deeply mourned by all peace loving people throughout the world. It is quite incumbent on all of those concerned with the Middle East process, of which Mr Rabin has been such a driving force, that that process be completed according to schedule because that will be the one lasting memorial to him for which he would most have wished.

PARA.TAB: To Mrs Leah Rabin, to whom Yitzhak Rabin was married for 47 years, and to her family, to the government and people of Israel, and to Jewish people throughout the world and, in particular, to the members of the Jewish community in Australia, I join other speakers today in offering my deepest sympathy.

TALK.START.PARA: —Throughout history people who tower in the making of civilisation have come from the land of Israel. That is absolute fact. Yitzhak Rabin now joins their company.

—It is symbolic and appropriate that in death Prime Minister Yitzhak Rabin was as potent a force for peace as he was during his life. His death reinforces the drive for peace. No one person had ever previously managed to gather together so many former enemies and people who are still far from being Israel's close friends or supporters in peace, in Israel, bringing a genuine sense of sympathy and support for its people.

PARA.TAB: The leaders of the Arab world who attended Prime Minister Rabin's funeral leave a far more significant and lasting impact than the mindless celebrations of his death by a few extremists. But even these extremists demonstrate, by their response, the effectiveness of Yitzhak Rabin in bringing about the peace that will rob extremists on all sides of their only claim to notoriety—by removing the basis of the hatred and divisiveness on which they depend for their existence.

When I visited Israel in 1962, Jerusalem was a divided city. The Mandelbaum Gate led to a no-man's-land. The Wailing Wall was beyond the reach of Jews. Israel lived on the brink. Now at last, largely as a result of Yitzhak Rabin, firstly as a soldier and then as a peacemaker, these territorial problems are hopefully being resolved.

Today is not just a condolence motion on behalf of the Jews of Australia or those people like me with a Jewish background. This expression of grief is on behalf of all Australians who, while horrified by Prime Minister Rabin's death, are uplifted by his life. I support the motion.

TALK.START.PARA: —I fully endorse the remarks that Senator Baume and other senators have just made. Those of us who are associated with the Jewish community in some minor way feel the enormous loss that is, of course, associated with this vile act.

PARA.TAB: I, along with a number of my colleagues from both sides of this chamber and the House of Representatives, joined in a memorial service for Yitzhak Rabin in Melbourne last week. I do not think any of us could possibly come away from that ceremony without an enormous appreciation of the tremendous loss that has been experienced, as Senator Baume has said, not just by the Jewish community but by all people who are concerned about conflict and war, particularly in the Middle East. What struck me, when I listened to the reports coming out of Israel and the comments, particularly of Yitzhak Rabin's family, was not only the tremendous suffering but also the enormous courage that is involved in the struggle for peace.

What strikes me particularly is that Yitzhak Rabin and Yasser Arafat and people like Gerry Adams share one thing in common—that is, the tremendous courage it takes to struggle for peace, particularly when you have been so involved in the struggle for war. It takes enormous courage to take up arms against a very powerful enemy to defend your community, to defend your country, as you see it, to defend your class, as you see it. It takes even greater courage to put them down and seek a resolution of conflict through negotiated political means. I fully endorse this motion.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to associate myself with the remarks that have been made by both the Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Gareth Evans) and the leader of the coalition, Senator Hill. The tragic assassination last week of Prime Minister Rabin brought back some very vivid memories for me. I, like Senator Baume, spent some time in Israel in 1965, which was only a short time after Senator Baume's visit.

PARA.TAB: I, too, remember the state of Israel. Israel was just a fledgling state at that stage; it had been 17 years since the state had been in existence. It was a state which was still trying to consolidate its position in the area; a state which had no social intercourse with any of its neighbours—the only way of getting into Israel was, as Senator Baume mentioned, through the Mandelbaum Gate crossing no-man's-land, which I remember vividly as well. It was a young nation of people made up mainly of immigrants from other countries who were trying to establish themselves as a state in the area and as a state where they felt some sort of security.

Prime Minister Rabin had an outstanding military career. Remember that the Israel I know was the Israel prior to the 1967 conflict, the 1973 conflict and all of the other conflicts that Israel found itself facing over the 30 years that have passed since my time there. Prime Minister Rabin had an outstanding military career in this period. It must be remembered that at the end of that outstanding military career he probably fought his hardest fight—the fight for peace.

In military engagements you know who your enemies are; when you are fighting for peace they are sometimes very hard to identify. The fact that on this particular occasion the assassin was someone from within Prime Minister Rabin's own country means that it was one of those opponents who are impossible to identify. In his fight for peace, he has done more for Israel probably then he ever did as a military commander, even though I guess during those days it was a case of establishing their boundaries and consolidating their place as a state in the Middle East.

Certainly, in that fight for peace the late Prime Minister Yitzhak Rabin will be remembered as someone who sacrificed his life in the service of his country. We can only hope that his endeavours in the field of peace will be remembered by all those who seek to achieve those aims.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SCHACHT
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Small Business, Customs and Construction)

TALK.START.PARA: —Like all other members of the Senate, I wish to endorse the remarks of all senators in support of this motion. Last week I had the opportunity in my office late on Tuesday evening to watch live the funeral ceremony from Israel. No-one who watched that could have been other than completely moved by the remarks made by such an extraordinary range of political leaders. But without doubt the most moving speech, and one of the most moving I have ever heard, was by his granddaughter, who spoke so eloquently and movingly of a personal memory of her grandfather. I think that said more to any of those watching than all the other excellent remarks made by all those political leaders.

PARA.TAB: Certainly Prime Minister Rabin had a remarkable political life in Israel—a person who was born there in the 1920s, was a fighter for Israel's independence through all those wars, became Prime Minister in the 1970s, lost office and then returned nearly 20 years later to become Prime Minister again. He then became the leader for the peace movement and the establishment of the dialogue and now, what we all hope for, a permanent settlement with the Palestinian people.

There is no doubt that, in any terms of history, very few people in any country will play such a role as Prime Minister Rabin played in his country through his whole life. Clearly, he has been a remarkable figure in this century in terms of human events.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ellison Sen C.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to support this motion and at the outset offer my condolences to the family of Yitzhak Rabin, and particularly to the people in the state of Israel and the members of the Jewish community in Australia. I came across a quote the other day in relation to this matter which I thought was rather interesting. It is entitled `Soldier of peace'. It states:

SPEECH.PARA: The soldier lived to become a man of peace, yet the man of peace met the death of a soldier, his body torn by bullets. Perhaps there is no contradiction in the first part of the statement, only a paradox. We justify war by saying that it begets peace, that through death we bring life, and so on. By this logic, the Yitzhak Rabin who led Israel's army to triumph in the Six Day War shares everything but tactics with the Yitzhak Rabin who shook the hand of Yasser Arafat on the White House lawn. The warrior and the conciliator formed two sides of the same soul, seeking one result.

And so it was that on the weekend, at the 11th hour of the 11th day of the 11th month, we remembered the sacrifices made by people who fought for this country in the endeavour to find peace. I believe that one can draw a comparison with that when one looks at the life of Yitzhak Rabin. Not only was he involved in fighting for his country in the 1940s and in the Arab-Israeli war in 1948 and in the Six-Day War, in which he played such a crucial role, but also he was involved in securing the state of Israel's security in the years after that.

PARA.TAB: Of course, he himself stated that the time had come to stop war, to stop the bloodshed and to endeavour to resolve the matter. In fact, in the same speech Senator Short quoted from—it was to be his last speech, to 100,000 or so people gathered for a peace rally—he said:

As we once took up our role in war, we must now work to find a solution to the most complex issue of the Israeli-Arab conflict, the Israeli-Palestinians conflict. It is not easy, it is painful, but there is no alternative.

SPEECH.PARA: Unfortunately, it takes great men—and there are very few of them—like Yitzhak Rabin to realise when there has been too much war, when there has been too much bloodshed, and when the time has come for the killing to stop. Unfortunately, as frail human beings we seem to have a history of going through a cycle of war and killing and then peace. It seems to be a never-ending cycle in the history of man.

PARA.TAB: But always at the crossroads there are remarkable men like Yitzhak Rabin who say to their fellow human beings, `Enough is enough. There is no alternative. We must now seek peace. The end to all this killing has come.' But, of course, usually in such cases those people pay the ultimate price. One has only to look through history to see where great men and women have paid the ultimate price. So it was that he paid the ultimate price after that speech to that peace rally.

I think we have to reflect on the times we now face, which are very different to the times Yitzhak Rabin faced in the 1960s, 1970s and perhaps the early 1980s. We do have a very different world today. We have a world without a Berlin Wall, we have a world where eastern Europe has changed dramatically and we even have a situation where there are endeavours for peace in Ireland.

So hopefully the time has come when we are entering into a new era of peace in this world although, unfortunately, that does not exist in Bosnia. I think it is incumbent on us as leaders of our country to endeavour to keep the fight for peace going. I think Yitzhak Rabin's contribution in this regard should be upheld and maintained and perhaps his death used as a marker for good. Perhaps we can use that as a rallying point, a focal point, to keep alive the peace prospects in the Middle East and, more importantly, the endeavours for peace worldwide.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —Isn't it ironic that Mr Rabin, a trained soldier, met his death not in the field of battle against an adversary but by an assassin's bullet, in the pursuit of peace. Anyone who has had any military training and has been involved in the armed services realises that the ultimate end of that training is the peace and the security of the people to be defended. That, of course, was the goal of Mr Rabin.

PARA.TAB: When I heard of Mr Rabin's death, I wrote a letter to the ambassador expressing, on my own behalf as a senator for Tasmania, my condolences. I expressed those condolences also on behalf of my family and indeed I expressed a hope that peace would prevail. To those who hope for peace, Mr Rabin's assassination was a great shock, particularly so for those who pray daily for peace. That was evident at our local parish church on the morning after the assassination when the celebrant and the congregation offered prayers for Mr Rabin, for the people of Israel and for all the people living in the Middle East, and particularly for peace.

For those who hope and pray for peace, this shock is not a shock of despair because we can pray confidently that God will turn this tragedy into good. What more good can come of it than a renewed determination to achieve a just and lasting peace for all the people of the Middle East. I quote from the book of Isaiah, which is a shared, inspired work:

SPEECH.PARA: Fair judgement will fix its home

PARA.TAB: in the desert,

SPEECH.PARA: and uprightness live in this orchard,
and the product of uprightness

PARA.TAB: will be peace,

SPEECH.PARA: the effect of uprightness

PARA.TAB: being quiet and security for ever.

SPEECH.PARA: Mr Rabin came to respect his former adversaries—the Palestinians, the Jordanians and the Egyptians—and that respect is founded deeply on the understanding that all human beings are created equal and that there is an inherent dignity that has been given by their creator which needs to be respected.

PARA.TAB: Unfortunately, I was not able to be in Sydney for the commemoration service at the synagogue. But I can assure the representatives of Israel and the people of Israel that the prayers of many thousands of persons are with them in this their time of sorrow. The time for war is well past and now is the time for peace. Shalom.

TALK.START.PARA: —In closing the debate, I would like to add just a few words of my own. It is always a disadvantage to speak last because most things have already been said. Of course, I support all of those things that have been said.

PARA.TAB: I visited Israel in April this year as a guest of the Knesset and, together with the Minister for Defence, Senator Robert Ray, hosted a dinner for Prime Minister Rabin at the famous King David Hotel in Jerusalem. Also, because I was sitting next to her, I had a very long discussion with the Prime Minister's wife, Leah, and I must say I was impressed with her knowledge of Australia, with her very deep knowledge of Australian art and with her fondness for Australia—particularly for the city of Melbourne, but for Australia as a whole.

I found both of them to be extremely engaging people. Mr Rabin was, above all, a realist who had seen the limits of what could be gained from war and knew that, if there were to be any lasting peace, real changes would have to be made. His land for peace policies were based on pragmatic confidence building measures designed to lock Palestinians into ever increasing responsibilities for the peace process. He could do this because the majority of Israelis knew him to be tough in ensuring their own security yet willing to try a new path to peace. He had seen how the intifada had broadened the scope of the conflict and how the policies of the past had alarmed even those close friends of Israel. He was aware of the risks from those who believed might would always be right. But he did not waiver in his determination.

However, it must have been extremely hurtful to him to have been called a Nazi by some Jews, knowing how offensive that association is to all Jews. Yet he carried on. As others have already said, I can only hope that his untimely death continues to unify the people of Israel and that they press ahead with the peace program. As has already been alluded to, polls yesterday showed that the vast majority of Israelis want this to happen. It would be a fitting tribute if his death were a catalyst in some sort of existentialist way, if that is not in conflict with Judaism, for real peace in the Middle East.

I support the motion and add my condolences, through you, Mr Ambassador, to the people of Israel, to the Jewish Diaspora and, more particularly, to his widow, Leah, and to her family. I ask honourable senators to stand in silence to signify their assent to the motion.

SPEECH.PARA: SENATE SELECT COMMITTEE ON PUBLIC INTEREST WHISTLEBLOWING
Ministerial Statement

PARA.TAB: The Senate Select Committee on Public Interest Whistleblowing was established by resolution of the Senate on 2 September 1993. On 27 October 1993 the Senate referred to the committee for inquiry and report the Whistleblowers Protection Bill 1993, a private senator's bill.

The committee received 125 submissions and 12 supplementary submissions, in addition to a number of written responses to evidence and submissions. It took oral evidence at public hearings over 7 hearing days in November 1993 and January and March in 1994. The report of the committee was tabled in the Senate on 30 August 1994. An interim government response was tabled on 29 November 1994. The interim response stated that the government would endeavour to present a comprehensive response in February 1995. However, the government response was deferred to await the report of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs on the protection of confidential and third party information, the report of the commission of inquiry into the Australian Secret Intelligence Service and the government response to the public service act review group.

I wish to express my thanks to the committee for its efforts. The subject of whistleblowing has been increasingly an issue on the national agenda. It is likely that the committee's report signifies the beginning of a new attitude to the general subject of whistleblowing. That state of affairs is consistent with the now well established philosophy of this government to develop modern, responsible managerial practices in public administration, which serve as a guide to the whole community.

The government has decided to give `in principle' approval to the development of whistleblower legislation that will strengthen the position of public spirited citizens within our modern managerial framework. First, however, I will shortly outline to you several matters which are relevant to whistleblowing.

I am informed that there are two reports which have a direct bearing on both the protection and disclosure of information and public service administration: The House of Representatives Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs report on the protection of confidential and third party information and the report of the Public Service Act review group. These reports raise issues of direct relevance to any proposed whistleblowing scheme, and it is appropriate to consider the detail of a whistleblowing scheme in the light of the recommendations contained within these reports.

I also note that the public report of the commission of inquiry into the Australian secret intelligence service supported the Gibbs committee's recommendations on the protection of whistleblowers. The government considers whistleblowing legislation to be an integral part of its response to the recommendations of the Samuels commission.

In addition, the guidelines on official conduct of Commonwealth public servants, a revised edition of which was issued in march 1995, have been amended to explain how a disclosure of information can be made under existing laws and the protection that is currently available to whistleblowers. It should also be noted that the financial management and accountability bill will give responsibility to managers for identifying and responding to instances of maladministration.
I seek leave to table the government's response to the committee's recommendations.

While that response indicates the government's proposed course of action on the issue of whistleblowing, I believe a short statement to explain the government's proposed whistleblowing scheme is appropriate.

The government understands the term whistleblowing to refer to the disclosure, in the public interest, of information which indicates wrongdoing. The public interest is in the fair and independent investigation of such allegations of wrongdoing, and the protection of a whistleblower from recrimination in the course of his or her employment following his or her disclosure of information.

The government intends to introduce into parliament legislation for the protection of whistleblowers and the investigation of their allegations. In the Commonwealth sphere whistleblowing is hindered by provisions of the Crimes Act 1914 prohibiting the disclosure of official information. In December 1991 the Gibbs committee, in its review of Commonwealth criminal law, made certain recommendations for the reform of the laws on the disclosure of official information. The public report of the commission of inquiry into the Australian Security Intelligence Service also recommended the introduction of whistleblowing legislation. It will be appropriate to introduce laws on whistleblowing both as a part of the government's implementation of the Gibbs committee's recommendations and as part of the government's response to the recommendations of the Samuels committee's inquiry into ASIS.

The scheme will be based upon a two stage process: whistleblowing disclosure within a department or agency, then to an independent agency. This process is identical to the basis of the committee's proposed scheme, and parallels arrangements that have been successful in other contexts, such as police complaints. The legislation will apply to Commonwealth officers and contractors. It will encourage them to use internal reporting mechanisms in the first instance in the form of an officer authorised to receive whistleblowing disclosures. The legislation will also provide for the use of existing independent reporting agencies—the Ombudsman and the Inspector-General of Intelligence and Security (the IGIS)—to ensure that disclosures are received and investigated. The government anticipates that access to the MPRA will ensure that whistleblowers who are Commonwealth officers are protected from retaliation in the course of their employment. Government contractors and their employees will receive similar protection from recrimination by Commonwealth officers through the ombudsman or the IGIS, as appropriate. Consequential amendments will be made to the relevant legislation to ensure that these independent agencies have the jurisdiction and powers appropriate to ensuring that the objectives of the proposed whistleblowing scheme are achieved.

SPEECH.PARA: The committee emphasised that potential whistleblowers need to be reassured that their disclosures will be fully and properly investigated by an appropriate independent agency that is accountable for its activities. The Ombudsman will be required to oversee the operation of the whistleblowing scheme and prepare information for inclusion in his or her annual report. The IGIS will oversee the operation of the whistleblowing scheme in the intelligence and security agencies.

PARA.TAB: The government proposes that an authorised officer, who represents the internal reporting mechanism, will be required to notify the Ombudsman of receipt of the whistleblower's complaint. The Ombudsman will have certain discretionary powers which may be exercised over the authorised officer's investigation of the disclosure. The authorised officer's decision to investigate the matter or not, to refer the matter to the Ombudsman or IGIS for investigation, or the result of the investigation, will be communicated to the whistleblower. If the whistleblower is dissatisfied with the authorised officer's decision not to investigate or with the result of the investigation, the whistleblower may take the matter to the Ombudsman or IGIS.

The Ombudsman or IGIS will have a range of powers to investigate a whistleblower's allegations, including the power to refuse to do so. They will also have the power to refer the matter to any other appropriate agency, such as the Auditor-General or the Privacy Commissioner, to be dealt with as that agency sees fit.

The government does not consider it appropriate for a whistleblower to make public disclosures either before using the whistleblowing scheme or before a final determination has been made on the allegations. Whistleblowing allegations are serious matters requiring careful investigation. The information available to a whistleblower may not be complete. Nor is the whistleblower usually in a position to make an independent assessment of the public interest considerations. The Ombudsman and the IGIS, on the other hand, are disinterested third parties who have powers and expertise to conduct full investigations, to assess the allegations in their full context and to make judgements about the action required. Both the Ombudsman and the IGIS have the public interest as their primary concern.

The public interest in creating a whistleblowing scheme is in the fair and independent investigation of allegations made by whistleblowers. Public disclosures may impair any investigation into the allegation. Whistleblowers who publicly disclose material after an investigation is complete will need to ensure that any such disclosure does not breach existing secrecy and privacy laws or the limits of their authorisation to disclose information. The Ombudsman will have a discretion to make public statements about whistleblowing matters as is appropriate. The Ombudsman will also include information about whistleblowing in his or her annual report. Existing powers to make special reports to the Prime Minister or parliament by the Ombudsman or the MPRA will apply to whistleblowing matters.

The government has given detailed consideration to all of the committee's recommendations and acknowledges the substantial assistance it has obtained from the committee's report in formulating the first scheme for the protection of whistleblowers and the investigation of their allegations at the Commonwealth level.

Report: Government Response
SENATOR THE HON GARETH EVANS QC
MINISTER FOR FOREIGN AFFAIRS
SENATOR ROBERT RAY
LEADER OF THE GOVERNMENT IN THE SENATE AND MINISTER FOR DEFENCE
PARLIAMENT HOUSE
CANBERRA ACT 2600
23 October 1995
The Hon Roger Price MP
Chairperson
Joint Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade
Parliament House
CANBERRA ACT 2600
Dear Mr Price

In the attachment to this letter we set out the Government's Response to your Committee's Report entitled "Australia's Participation in Peace Keeping", which was tabled in Parliament on 8 December last year. In doing so, we wish to make a number of general points on behalf of the Government.

The Government finds the Report to be a useful document which focuses public attention on the increasing importance and complexity of peace keeping operations. The Report also draws attention to Australia's increased participation in peace keeping, and the multi-dimensional nature of that participation. The Australian Defence Force (ADF) has contributed in varying ways to more than 20 of the 33 United Nations peace keeping operations undertaken since World War II. The ADF has demonstrated a high degree of adaptability in being able to provide individuals, groups of specialists and formed military units for the complex political and military operations which epitomise contemporary multi dimensional peace keeping. The Australian Federal Police (AFP) has also had a long history of involvement in the law and order aspects of peace keeping operations, but as the United Nations operations in Cambodia, Mozambique and Haiti indicate, the AFP has acquired much broader responsibilities such as investigating human rights violations, training local police officers to rebuild or create the local police force, verifications of local elections and a range of humanitarian tasks. As the nature of peace operations has expanded, so too has the need for the services of other non-military Government agencies, such as the Australian Electoral Commission (AEC). The AEC's involvement in providing international electoral assistance within the context of United Nations peace keeping operations began in the United Nations Transition Assistance Group for Namibia (UNTAG) in late 1989 and continued in the Western Sahara, Cambodia and Mozambique.

The multidimensional nature of Australia's participation in peace keeping operations was demonstrated in the United Nations Transitional Authority in Cambodia (UNTAC) in which the ADF, the AFP and the AEC all made significant contributions. In the current international environment, it seems likely that the specialist capabilities and experience of Australian military and civilian agencies will continue to be keenly sought after in peace operations.

As a result, we are particularly encouraged by the fact that the Committee's Report generally endorses the Government's approach to multinational peace keeping operations and its efforts to make constructive contributions to the process of improving United Nations peace keeping.

In the last few years, the increasing number of highly ambitious United Nations operations have clearly tested the ability of the international community to respond to crises which in turn has highlighted the need to reconsider the way we conduct peace operations. Many of the recommendations made by your Committee correspond to reforms of processes and resource allocations which have recently begun to be addressed by the United Nations and are being pursued by the Government.

Inevitably, the expansion of United Nations peace keeping operations has increased the level of risk to the safety of United Nations personnel. In this context, one particularly important reform in which the Government has been actively involved, is the establishment of an international legal regime to protect United Nations personnel. Australia negotiated and co-sponsored the "Convention on the Safety of United Nations and Associated Personnel", adopted by the United Nations General Assembly in 1994. The Government is currently working to ensure early adherence to the Convention through signature and ratification in order to send a clear message that the international community will not tolerate attacks on United Nations personnel.

Australia has also made a substantial contribution to a number of informal groups dedicated to reforming peace keeping operations including three working groups established after the Ottawa Conference in April 1994, which dealt with the political direction and support of peace keeping operations, command and control issues, and training. Another positive development in the international effort to strengthen United Nations peace keeping was a Presidential Statement by the United Nations Security Council which announced that measures would be put in place to enhance consultation arrangements between the Security Council, the United Nations Secretariat and troop-contributing nations. Australia has also contributed to the debate on improving the UN's rapid deployment capability.
The Government is continuing to consider ways of improving certain aspects of Australia's participation in peace keeping operations.
We thank you and the members of your Committee for this Report.
Yours sincerely
