THE AUSTRALIAN GOVERNMENT RESPONSE
to
THE JOINT STANDING COMMITTEE ON FOREIGN AFFAIRS, DEFENCE AND TRADE REPORT:
"AUSTRALIA'S PARTICIPATION IN PEACE KEEPING"
Recommendation 1

The Committee recommends that the Department of Defence and the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade consult with appropriate Non-Government Organisations to agree as a matter of urgency on a common terminology with respect to peace keeping (paras 1.3-1.8)
Agreed in Principle

When the Australian Foreign Minister, Senator Evans, launched his book, "Cooperating For Peace" at the forty eighth United Nations General Assembly, one of its key aims was to develop an agreed vocabulary for the range of possible responses to international security problems. Significant progress has been made in this respect but a degree of confusion regarding terminology still persists and as United Nations peace operations continue to increase in number and complexity, the need to clarify this confusion has never been greater. "Cooperating for Peace" has provided a useful basis for agreed terminology within the Government.

Common terminology is also addressed in a number of documents produced by the Australian Defence Force Peacekeeping Centre. This terminology is largely in accordance with current United Nations practice which in turn now largely coincides with the "Cooperating for Peace" terminology. The Government will continue to develop agreed national terminology and draw on the doctrinal assets of the Australian Defence Force Peacekeeping Centre.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Chapter Two—The Changing Global Perspective: Implications for the United Nations

SPEECH.PARA: Recommendation 2
The Committee recommends that the Australian Government make provisions for the fluctuating nature of its peace keeping commitments in its budget arrangements for peace keeping. (para 2.10)
Agreed in Principle

Current budgetary arrangements enable Departments' funding bases to be adjusted where provision of additional funding for peace operations is agreed by the Government on a case by case basis. The existing budgetary arrangements are considered to be adequate to cater for the scale of most likely future commitments.

The Committee recommends that the Australian Government give greater recognition to the increasing importance of the civilian functions in peace keeping operations and seek to place appropriately skilled Australians in United Nations headquarters as well as in specified peace keeping missions. (para 2.16)
Agreed in Principle

In recent years, United Nations peace keeping operations have become increasingly multidimensional and have included a wide range of civilian functions such as civilian policing, electoral assistance, civil administration, public information, human rights monitoring, refugee repatriation and humanitarian assistance. The level of involvement of Australians, both from relevant Government agencies and private individuals, has been increasing throughout this period and there is scope, in terms of expertise and experience, to further that level of involvement. The Government is currently pursuing a strategy to place Australian nationals in key positions throughout the United Nations system, including agencies involved in United Nations peace keeping operations.

The Committee recommends that the Australian Government give serious consideration to the likely prospects for ongoing peace and stability before committing Australian personnel to peace keeping. (para 2.24)
Agreed

The extent of commitment of the warring parties to the operation is one of the key criteria examined in the planning process. It is difficult, however, to predict with any certainty whether peace and stability will or will not follow the commencement of any peace operation. There are obvious risks associated with any peace operation and these are factors which have to be fully considered before commitment of Australian personnel. Where such risks are involved, plans are made for the withdrawal of the Australian contingent in an emergency.

The Committee recommends that the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade continue its efforts to focus the attention of the international community on preventive strategies and peace building.(para 2.26)
Agreed

Two priority tasks of the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade included in the Department's 1994-96 Corporate Plan, demonstrate the Government's commitment to focusing the international community on preventive strategies and peace building. These are enhancing the regional security environment based on acceptance of cooperative security approaches, and strengthening the effectiveness of the United Nations in cooperative security arrangements.

To this end, Australia has drafted a resolution on "Peace Building and Preventive Diplomacy" and is working to have it adopted by the United Nations General Assembly this year. Preventive approaches are also being pursued regionally through the ASEAN Regional Forum (ARF) where a paper was presented to an ARF Intersessional Seminar on preventive diplomacy in Seoul in May 1995
The Committee recommends that the Australian Government exert pressure on the international community to enter into the process of reform of the United Nations.(para 2.29-2.32)
The Committee recommends that the Australian Government continues to press for urgent reform within the United Nations in New York.(para 2.80)
Agreed

The Government has been active in contributing to the process of promoting United Nations reform, including improving the United Nations' capacity to plan and manage peace keeping operations. The Australian Foreign Minister, Senator Evans's book, "Cooperating for Peace", put forward concrete proposals for United Nations reform. These proposals form the basis of the Government's ongoing efforts in this area. A paper summarising current Australian initiatives is at Annex A.

The Committee recommends that the Australian Government support current efforts to increase the safety of United Nations peace keeping personnel, including through developing an effective international legal regime. (para 2.45)
Agreed

The Government fully supported the negotiations of the "Convention on the Safety of United Nations and Associated Personnel", and co-sponsored the United Nations Resolution which adopted the Convention by consensus. Australia has been active in supporting the draft Convention on Safety of United Nations Personnel. This Convention addresses the question of responsibility for attacks on United Nations and associated personnel and measures to ensure that those responsible for such attacks are brought to justice.

Adoption of the Convention is an important achievement which will promote the basis for action against deliberate acts of violence which strike United Nations personnel. The Convention is open for signature until 31 December 1995. The Attorney-General's Department is now working with the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade, and the Department of Defence towards early adherence to the Convention through signature and ratification as a clear indication that Australia supports it and that attacks upon United Nations associated personnel will not be tolerated.

The Committee recommends that the Australian Government make available to the United Nations officers with particular expertise in the development of concepts of operations and strategic planning. (para 2.47)

The Committee recommends that the Australian Government urge the United Nations to expand the planning cell of the United Nations Secretariat to include military, civilian and financial experts. (para 2.52)

The Committee recommends that the Australian Government make available middle to high ranking officers, both military and civilian, on a long-term basis to the United Nations General Staff for Peace Keeping. (para 2.61)
The Committee recommends that the Australian Government provide resources to the United Nations to assist in the development of a consistent command and control doctrine. (para 2.66)
Agreed in Principle

Australia currently provides seven military officers to United Nations Headquarters (UNHQ), New York, in the Department of Peace Keeping Operations (DPKO), filling a number of key staff appointments in the operations, planning and logistics fields. These postings are seen as a valuable contribution to the enhanced efficiency of the DPKO and to the development of its peace keeping operations doctrine. This number is disproportionately high in relation to our total peace operation contribution, reflecting the United Nations' considerable regard for the quality of Australian Defence Force personnel. However, Australia is not regarded as a major or medium level contributor to peace operations and cannot be expected to be given a leading reformist's role while that is the case. Australia will continue to consider requests to provide staff to UNHQ on a case by case basis.
The Committee recommends that the Australian Government urge the United Nations to appoint and involve force commanders early in the planning stages of peace keeping operations (para 2.50)
Agreed

In theory, early involvement in operational level planning by a force commander (FC) and his staff can significantly contribute to the effective insertion of a United Nations force, provided the advice of the FC-designate is taken by UNHQ. However, it must be recognised that this may be difficult to achieve unless a FC-designate can assemble all his multi-national key headquarters staff during the planning phase of a United Nations operation. This modus operandi would be desirable to establish cohesion in a United Nations Force Headquarters and would make a worthwhile contribution to successful initial planning.

The Committee recommends that the Australian Government urge the United Nations to establish a strategic level headquarters comparable to the strategic headquarters of a national defence force; and that at the strategic level headquarters also include representatives of civilian organisations. (paras 2.54-2.56)
The Committee recommends that the Australian Government urge the United Nations to create a United Nations General Staff for Peace Keeping. (para 2.61)
Agreed in principle

The United Nations Secretariat functions as the strategic headquarters for United Nations operations, and the staff of the DPKO performs similar functions to a General Staff. We recognise that the current arrangements in the DPKO are inadequate to deal with the range of peace keeping operations. That is why Australia will continue to urge that the UNHQ military staff develop a sound organisational and manning framework to enable the efficient mounting of peace operations, particularly in the areas of logistics and contingency/future planning.

The Committee recommends that the Australian Government urge the United Nations to provide Special Representatives and Force Commanders with the funds, staff and authority which would allow them to run their missions in a more autonomous and efficient manner.(para 2.61)
Agreed

The Government has consistently argued that the United Nations needs to give greater autonomy to Special Representatives and Force Commanders. We believe they should be given the funds, staff and authority to run day to day operations in a more autonomous manner.

The Committee recommends that the Australian Government urge the United Nations to establish a permanent full-time command and control operations centre in United Nations Headquarters to support the field commanders and to integrate the operational, logistic, planning and intelligence requirements of each peace keeping operation; and that a liaison officer for each force commander be located at the command and control operations centre. (para 2.65)
Agreed in Part

Australia continues to actively encourage United Nations to reform its command and control of peace keeping operations especially in developing better mechanisms for providing strategic military advice to the Security Council. The Government is receptive to proposals from Member States, such as the current Canadian Study for improving the United Nations' rapid reaction capability, to increase overall effectiveness. It should be noted that there have been a number of organisational changes in the Secretariat and recent structural changes in DPKO which will, when fully implemented, bring about some of the integration proposed in the recommendation. A Situation Centre has been established within DPKO, manned by military and civilian officers, and is responsible for the day to day monitoring of United Nations operations. This centre provides daily reports on each United Nations mission to Permanent Missions in New York. The Australian Defence Force has an officer posted to this centre. The location of dedicated Mission Liaison officers within the Situation Centre would, in practice, prove inefficient and would duplicate existing lines of communication between Force Commanders and military and political officers in the United Nations in New York.
The Committee recommends that the Australian Government continue to respond positively to requests for Australian participation in peace keeping operations. (para 4.1)
The Committee recommends that the Australian Government retain case by case consideration of requests to contribute forces to peace keeping. (para 4.2)
Agreed in principle

The Government is committed to maintaining its support for the United Nations, particularly in the area of participation in peace operations. However, we will continue to consider requests on a case by case basis and this may, for a variety of reasons, preclude on occasions a positive response to a United Nations request.
The Committee recommends that the Department of Defence be provided with full supplementation for costs incurred where overseas deployments are involved. (para 4.12)
The Committee recommends that the Government reimburse the Department of Defence for all expenditure on peace keeping activities. (para 7.27)
Agreed in Part

Where agreed by Government, the Department of Defence is currently provided with full supplementation for the additional costs it incurs in undertaking peace operations. There will, however, be other circumstances where supplementation would not normally be provided; for example, where the commitment of Department of Defence resources to a peace operation will only involve minor additional costs, or where participation in the peace operation is in the direct interests of the defence of Australia.

It is not agreed that the consideration of the provision of supplementation for the additional costs of peace operations be limited to those instances where overseas deployments are involved. The Commonwealth's contribution to peace operations might include a range of responses which do not involve overseas deployment, including for example, the provision of training to other forces, but which would nevertheless incur additional costs.

The 1994 Defence White Paper, "Defending Australia", notes the current practice that the Department of Defence meets the cost of relatively minor deployments and the Government supplements the Department of Defence's budget for the cost of larger peace operations.

The Committee recommends that the Government develop and publish an integrated policy on peace keeping, taking into account the diversity of peace keeping activities and objectives in the evolving international order.(para 4.36)
The Committee recommends that criteria should be developed for determining when Australia should contribute to and withdraw from peace keeping and enforcement operations.(paras 4.78-4.81)
Agreed

The Government recently set out criteria for determining Australia's involvement in peace operations, in the 1994 Defence White Paper, "Defending Australia". The criteria include: whether the operation has clear and achievable goals and clearly defined review and termination points; what costs the contribution might incur; what our commitment to other operations is at the time; having regard among other things to our reputation as a supporter of the United Nations; community attitudes; training benefits to the Defence Organisation; and what risk to personnel is involved.
The Committee recommends that the Government examine the feasibility of allocating an annual amount for peace keeping. (para 4.38)
Not Agreed

Current budgetary arrangements, whereby supplementation is provided as agreed by Government for any additional costs incurred, appear adequate. Should the need arise, the Government will examine alternative arrangements. See also response to Recommendation 2.

The Committee recommends that a permanent secretariat be established to coordinate peace keeping policy and decision-making. The secretariat staff should include representatives of all organisations involved in peace keeping missions, namely the Department of Defence, Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade, Department of Prime Minister and Cabinet, Australian Federal Police, Australian Electoral Commission, non-Government Organisations, the Defence Industry Committee and private suppliers. The secretariat should be sufficiently flexible to include representatives of other organisations which may come to be involved in peace keeping. (paras 4.76-4.77)
Not Agreed

Current Government procedures, through Interdepartmental Committees and the military planning process, provide effective interdepartmental consideration of any peace operation request on an as required basis. Provision exists within this structure to invite non-Government participants. For example, during preparation for the Australian Defence Force deployment to Rwanda, non-Government organisations were consulted during initial planning, together with the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade, the Australian Agency for International Development and the Attorney General's Department (for Status of Forces Agreement considerations).
The Committee recommends that any decision for Australian troops to operate under Chapter VII provisions of the United Nations Charter be endorsed by the Australian Parliament (para 4.83)
Not Agreed

Decisions on the involvement of Australia in peace operations in both warlike and non-warlike circumstances are made by the Executive Government. Decisions to deploy the Australian Defence Force overseas in support of Chapter VII enforcement operations, such as in the recent cases of Somalia and the Australian Defence Force commitment in the Gulf in 1990-91 in response to Iraq's invasion of Kuwait, were the subject of Cabinet consideration, after which Ministerial Statements were made in the Parliament.

The Committee recommends that Australia should continue to make specialised contributions to peace keeping operations which draw upon the particular expertise of the Australian Defence Force and Australian Federal Police and the experience in civilian areas such as electoral assistance and administration of justice.
Agreed

This Recommendation summarises the Government's current modus operandi. Based on an Australian Defence Force agreed list of available assets, Australia responds to requests for assistance on a case by case basis. It is normal for Australia, in common with other developed nations, to be invited to contribute specialist units to peace operations. Australian Federal Police and Australian Electoral Commission activities in Cambodia have also led to them being requested by the United Nations and provided by Australia for service in areas such as Mozambique and Haiti. The Australian Federal Police and the Australian Electoral Commission should continue to contribute to peace keeping operations where they will have a meaningful role to play.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Chapter Five—Impact on the Australian Defence Force

SPEECH.PARA: The Committee recommends that the Department of Defence consider international, and in particular United Nations, arrangements in force structure deliberations. (para 5.31)
Not Agreed

The requirements of the particular operation and the availability of units determine which elements we contribute to peace operations. We do not establish special units or earmark elements within the Australian Defence Force for peace operations. The United Nations requires different types of units for different operations. If we tried to predict United Nations needs we could restrict our flexibility to provide elements from our wide range of capabilities to meet the requirements of specific operations. The Australian Defence Force is structured for defending Australia, but the versatility in such a force ensures it can contribute to peace operations.
The Committee endorses the decision of the Government to create a fifth infantry battalion and recommends that it be established within two years. (para 5.67)
Agreed in Part

The Government's decision in the 1994 Defence White Paper, "Defending Australia", to raise a fifth infantry battalion enhances our capability for initial land operations in the defence of Australia. The battalion, which will include one Reserve company, will be raised over the next three to four years as the resources become available. It is acknowledged that this additional battalion maintained for the defence of Australia, will improve the versatility of the Force, provide greater flexibility for contributions to United Nations and other peace operations, and contribute to combined exercises in the region.
The Committee recommends that a register of the availability of General Reservists for peace keeping service be maintained; and that the register be updated on an annual basis. (para 5.76)
Agreed in Principle

This Recommendation will be implemented as part of the annual `availability for call-out' that will be completed by all Australian Defence Force active reserves (to be introduced in the near future). Systems will need to be developed to utilise this information in planning for peace operations. The declaration of availability for peace operations will necessarily be indicative only. Actual commitment would depend on the individual circumstances of the Reservist when the occasion arises.
The Committee recommends that the Australian Defence Force aim to reach a target figure of 25 per cent involvement of General Reserve in peace keeping activities. (para 5.76)
Not Agreed

The Australian Defence Force is committed to the participation of Active Reservists in peace operations and intends to include Reservists as part of the total force response to requests for peace keeping assistance. The level of contribution by Reservists in these activities necessarily needs to be determined on a case by case basis. The versatility of response should not be limited by attempting to allocate percentages to elements of the total force.

PARA.EMPHASIS: The Committee recommends that the Defence Act 1903 s.50F (1) be amended to insert the words
and peace keeping or peace operations

SPEECH.PARA: Agreed in Principle

Widening the scope of the Defence Act as suggested, provides greater flexibility in planning. However, the implications of this Recommendation warrant more detailed consideration. Among the issues warranting further consideration are the implications of call-out for both employers of Reserve personnel and Reserve personnel who are students at tertiary institutions. Government will be considering a range of issues relating to the employment of reserves in the context of its consideration of the Ready Reserve Report which was released by the Minister for Defence on 1 August 1995.
The Committee recommends that legislation be enacted to ensure civilian employment of the reserve personnel is protected for the period of call-up. (para 5.82)
Agreed

Service in the Reserve Force is voluntary and the period of enlistment is open ended to the point that Reserves are required to be used in the defence of the nation; in that case they would be subject to call-out. The term call-up is used to describe the process of involuntary military service or conscription.

Currently, as advised in the 1994 Defence White Paper, "Defending Australia", the Government is developing the basis for the protection of Reserves' interests on call-out, and one of the topics for consideration is a guarantee for the return to their civilian employment after call-out ceases. Employment protection is part of this issue and will require wide consultation before suitable policy and legislation can be developed. This is currently being undertaken by an Implementation Team within Australian Defence Force Headquarters.

The Committee recommends that the Department of Defence rigorously monitor the impact on Service Families of deployment on peace keeping missions, both during the deployment, and after the return, of Australian Defence Force personnel. (para 6.24)
Agreed

Procedures and structures are already in place to carry out this process. Family support is provided to the dependants and families of all Defence members by the four established Defence Welfare organisations:
.Australian Defence Families Information and Liaison Staff
(Tri-Service)
.Navy Personnel Services Organisation
.Army Community Services
.RAAF Social Worker and Information Services

Special and dedicated attention is directed to the dependants and families of members serving overseas or on extended absences in Australia. A Family Support Plan is tailored for each mission, and is closely monitored in pre-deployment, deployment and post-deployment phases.

Further, in response to a number of special needs identified during support to United Nations operations in Cambodia, Army established a Welfare Coordination Cell in Land Headquarters. This cell is dedicated to providing an information and referral service for the families of members of all services who are deployed under Army arrangements.

Commanding Officers and family support organisations have direct access to a number of specialist services to assist in the delivery of personnel and family support. These include military chaplains, psychologists, professional social workers, and members of accredited philanthropic services. All these resources, together with formal and informal unit-based support systems, ensure the delivery of a comprehensive and coordinated system of family support. The present system is considered to be effective, but it is closely monitored and subject to on going review and refinement to meet the changing needs of Defence families.
The Committee recommends that special funding be allocated to the Australian Federal Police to support its contribution to peace keeping.(para 7.34)
Agreed in Part
The Australian Federal Police presently receives funding for peace keeping operations on a case by case basis. Should the need arise, the Government will examine alternative arrangements.

The Committee recommends that the Australian Government support the development of, and inclusion of, "justice packages" as part of the peace keeping and peace building missions in countries where the rule of law, and the infrastructure needed to support it, have manifestly broken down.(para 8.19-8.21)
Agreed

Restoring law and order, and the infrastructure needed to support it, is often vital to the success of peace keeping operations and "justice packages" can be developed to ensure viable local legal systems. The reasons why the rule of law and infrastructure break down, are invariably complex. Such "justice packages" must draw upon universal principles and local personnel should be trained to take over their own systems. However, while "justice packages" are an important component in the restoration of law and order and the rehabilitation of government institutions, they are only one of a number of issues that must be addressed in developing sustainable solutions to complex emergencies. The Government supports the United Nations efforts aimed at comprehensive responses to international emergencies and, through cooperation between agencies, the development of strategies to facilitate the transition from relief to rehabilitation and development.

The Committee recommends that consideration be given to the feasibility of attaching a representative of the Australian Federal Police to the Australian Mission to the United Nations in New York.(para 8.46)
Agreed in Part

Currently, the Defence Attache in New York provides assistance to the Australian Federal Police. Attaching an officer of the Australian Federal Police to the Australian Mission to the United Nations in New York might achieve a more stable, selective, timely, and effective UNCIVPOL participation by the Australian Federal Police in United Nations sponsored peace keeping operations. However, this would be a matter for future workload assessment of the Australian Federal Police, to be conducted in the light of ongoing levels of Australian Federal Police involvement in United Nations operations.

The Committee recommends that the Australian Government provide the funding to enable the Australian Federal Police to expand its capacity to provide training opportunities for UNCIVPOL, especially in professionalism and human rights.( para 8.65)
Agreed

Where it can, the Australian Federal Police contributes to United Nations sponsored seminars. Recently it responded to the United Nations Centre for Human Rights' request to provide a trainer to instruct on international standards for human rights to the Brazilian Military Police in Rio de Janeiro and to the Former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia Police in Skopje. The development of regional CIVPOL training is also an achievable objective. Informal discussions with some of our regional neighbours' police forces, who regularly participate in peace keeping missions, confirm that there is a willingness to participate in regional training initiatives, including regular interchange of relevant personnel between regional nations, the conduct of regular multi-national training courses and seminars, the establishment of a permanent UNCIVPOL Regional Training School and in appropriate circumstances, the deployment of multi-national regional contingents.
The Committee recommends that the Australian Federal Police's peace keeping role be given formal recognition as one of its specific roles.(para 8.66)
Agreed in Part

International peace keeping is not an integral part of the raison d'etre of the Australian Federal Police. Peace keeping is briefly dealt with as part of the Australian Federal Police's Charter (Section 13(2) Ministerial Direction) under the sub-heading, "Role of the Australian Federal Police", including, "It will . . . .service Government law enforcement commitments to the United Nations." In the main, United Nations commitments are accommodated within current Australian Federal Police priorities.

The Committee recommends that the Australian Electoral Commission be included in the early planning phase of peace keeping operations in which the conduct of elections is a significant element of the mission.(para 8.78)
Agreed
The Government supports the Australian Electoral Commission's early involvement in the planning phase of peace keeping operations in which the conduct of elections is an element of the mission.
The Committee recommends that the finances allocated to the Australian Electoral Commission take into account its peace keeping function.(para 8.78)
Agreed in Principle

The Australian Electoral Commission is not currently budget funded to participate in peace keeping operations. However, inter-governmental organisations such as the United Nations and the Commonwealth Secretariat, and AusAID may provide funding on a case-by-case basis. Should the need arise, the Government will examine alternative arrangements.
Recommendation 42

The Committee recommends the Australian Defence Force appoint a liaison officer to contingents deployed on peace keeping to coordinate the work of the military with the activities of Non-Government Organisations. (para 9.22)
The Committee recommends that consideration be given by the Australian Defence Force to facilitating secondment of officers to Non-Government Organisations on rotation. (para 9.23)

The Committee recommends that the Australian Defence Force involve Non-Government Organisations in pre-deployment briefings with a view to drawing upon the in-country experience of Non-Government Organisation workers and setting up appropriate mechanisms for liaison while on deployment. (para 9.41)
Agreed in Part

The Australian Defence Force, as required, includes Non-Government Organisations' (NGOs) representatives in initial briefings and, if appropriate, planning. In mission areas, close liaison exists between deployed Australian Defence Force contingents and Australian NGOs. From the United Nations' perspective, coordination between United Nations' forces and NGOs is a Force Headquarters responsibility. Therefore, close liaison between the Australian Defence Force contingents and Australian NGOs needs to be mindful of Force policy and procedures. If appropriate, and mutually beneficial to the Australian Defence Force and NGOs, secondment would be considered.
The Committee recommends that the Australian Defence Force offer places in appropriate training courses to representatives of Non-Government Organisations.(para 9.48)
Agreed

NGOs have been invited to attend all Department of Defence organised peace keeping training seminars to date and will continue to be so. There is no impediment to offering places on Defence training courses to representatives of NGOs provided such training is consistent with Government and Department of Defence objectives. Government and Department of Defence policy would require the recovery of the full cost of providing such training, unless the requirement to recover costs was specifically waived. Any consideration of the waiver of full cost recovery would need to be on a case by case basis.

The Committee recommends that Cabinet contribute as much effort to post-deployment assistance as to the immediate needs of a crisis and factor both priorities into planning for a peace keeping response.(para 9.63)
Agreed in Principle

The Government agrees on the importance of factoring in longer term development needs in the early stages of an emergency response. However, Australia does not have the capacity to commit the substantial resources required to oversee long term assistance in all cases where it provides an emergency response. Decisions to provide long term assistance should be made on a case by case basis with reference to Australia's foreign policy interests and development cooperation objectives. The role of Australian humanitarian aid will be more limited
in regions which are well served by other donors or where they have special interests, responsibilities or proximity.
Recommendation 47

The Committee recommends that unless provision can be made for post-deployment assistance the value of contributing to peace keeping operations is diminished and should be rigorously reassessed.(para 9.63)
Agreed in Part

The Government agrees that post-conflict reconstruction after deployment is often of critical importance, and should be a priority concern of the international community. However, the Government does not agree with the implication that a national decision to contribute to a peace keeping operation should be re-assessed if there is no guaranteed provision for post-deployment assistance. Australia contributes to international efforts in many multinational peace keeping operations where the capacity to continue the commitment will in some cases be limited. Other donors with greater interests in the region in which the emergency occurs may pick up the rehabilitation and reconstruction phases.
Recommendation 48
The Committee recommends that the Australian Government take steps to encourage regional cooperation in the sphere of peace keeping. (para 10.27)
The committee recommends that the Australian Government encourage regional countries and major allies to become more engaged in and contribute to peace keeping operations. (para 10.27)
Agreed

As recently stated in the 1994 Defence White Paper, "Defending Australia", participation in United Nations peace operations also complements Australia's regional and alliance interests. Our participation in peace operations in Cambodia provided a constructive basis to increase cooperation with regional countries. We are making opportunities available to regional countries to undertake peace operations training with Australia, primarily through encouraging regional attendance at the Australian Defence Force Peacekeeping Centre, and are seeking ways of expanding this type of cooperative activity, including through regional discussions such as the ARF. By developing closer cooperation in peace operations with regional countries, we build confidence and contribute to cooperative regional security arrangements. For Australia to continue to play a leading role, we will need to retain both the perception that we are committed to supporting peace operations, and the knowledge and standing flowing from first-hand experience of these operations.

The Committee recommends that an Australian Peace Keeping Institute be established within the Australian Defence Studies Centre. Further, the Government undertake a feasibility study to determine whether or not the Australian Defence Studies Centre is the most appropriate location for the institute. (para 11.64)
Not Agreed

The Government recognises the multi-dimensional nature of peace keeping operations and already takes an integrated approach to the training and preparation of all civilian and military personnel for deployment in peace keeping operations. The academic study of peace keeping is already well covered by Australian academic institutions. The Departments of Foreign Affairs and Trade, and Defence currently provide significant funds to four academic institutions, which support research and publications on peace keeping. The Australian Defence Force Peacekeeping Centre at Williamtown provides training for multidimensional peace keeping operations, primarily for the Australian Defence Force, and is responsible for the development of the essential doctrine for the Australian Defence Force's involvement in peace keeping operations. The Centre also seeks to include other relevant Government Departments and NGOs in its training courses and development of doctrine. The Centre also provides training opportunities for regional countries, which is a concrete example of regional security cooperation. Although there may be scope to further develop the multi-dimensional and inter-disciplinary approaches taken by the Centre, the arguments in favour of a new institution and the issue of its location within Australian Defence Studies Centre have not been adequately substantiated, and the Government considers that a feasibility study is not warranted at this stage.

PARA.EMPHASIS: ANNEX A: CURRENT AUSTRALIAN INITIATIVES WITHIN

SPEECH.PARA: THE UNITED NATIONS

(a) Promoting Australia's concept of co-operative security, with an emphasis on preventive approaches and the United Nation's capacity for peace building and the peaceful settlement of disputes, not least because these are more cost-effective than the current emphasis on reactive measures. Priority goals for 1995 have been the promotion of Australia's preventive diplomacy draft resolution and progress towards establishing a more representative Security Council. Australia worked in the annual session in April of the UN Special Committee on Peace Keeping Operations to bring greater clarity in defining the objectives and mandates of United Nations operations, and to strengthen the United Nations' capacity to plan operations. Australia also circulated amongst Special Committee members the conclusions of the April Stockholm International Peace Research Institute (SIPRI) seminar on the use of force in peace operations and contributed to the debate on improving the United Nation's rapid deployment capacity. The Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade presented a paper on the division of labour between the United Nations and regional organisations for a major international conference at La Trobe University in July and is also working on a joint paper with the Dutch on improving the effectiveness of sanctions regimes.

(b) Identifying means of "re-integrating" United Nations activities and enhancing system-wide co-ordination, including by developing proposals in the Agenda for Development Working Group to further enhance the Economic and Social Council's role in system-wide co-ordination as well as through suggesting better arrangements for humanitarian relief operations. The Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade has been identifying concrete ways of promoting a more coordinated and integrated approach to the work of United Nations bodies including program effectiveness and limiting duplication, including at the Economic and Social Council and in major United Nations meetings. The Department's specific proposals in the economic and social areas include implementing measures to monitor the performance of the machinery for United Nations humanitarian relief coordination, promoting the Beijing Women's Conference as a "conference of commitments", efforts to strengthen the human rights treaty system, pressing for the collocation of secretariats of various environment conventions in Geneva and our efforts to streamline the Economic and Social Commission for Asia and the Pacific's annual sessions.

(c) Pursuing increased administrative efficiency and program focus in the specialised agencies and greater responsiveness to member states' needs, by continuing to pursue improved budget, financial and program management and to promote the extension of worthwhile reforms across the United Nations system such as the management reforms introduced in the Secretariat in New York. Australia will continue to participate in multi-donor agency evaluations such as that for the United Nations Children's Fund and Rwanda and maintain Australia's leading role in the World Health Organisation and reforms of the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization.

(d) Addressing the United Nation's financial problems and working to match allocation of resources to evolving priorities, in the United Nations itself and across the United Nations system. Australia is assessing how to pursue its proposals for improving peace keeping financing procedures; which were partly adopted by the United Nations Fifth Committee in December 1994, although the greater focus this year is likely to be on reviewing the scale of assessments for peace keeping payments. Australia will remain a leading advocate of introducing incentives to promote prompt payment of regular budget and peace keeping payments, and will be participating in efforts through the Geneva Group to identify areas for savings in United Nations programs that can be redeployed into priority areas. The United Nations mission in New York plans to develop proposals for the review of the major United Nations financial oversight bodies as a Canada Australia and New Zealand (CANZ) group exercise.

(e) Creating more competent United Nations secretariats, including support for the introduction of modern management practices and greater accountability. Australia will develop further the case for top-level restructuring to introduce four Deputy Secretaries-General and build on the work of our United Nations General Assembly 49 delegation which co-ordinated the key resolution giving Member States' backing to personnel reforms. Australia will continue to promote gender equity as a tenet of United Nations personnel policy.

Senator Barney Cooney
Chair

Parliament House
CANBERRA ACT 2600
Dear Senator Cooney
I am writing in response to your Committee's report, tabled on 21 September 1995, on the Sex Discrimination Amendment Bill 1995.
The Government appreciates the work the Committee has done reviewing the Bill and providing recommendations to improve its clarity and efficacy.
The Government's response to the recommendations made by the majority of the Committee follows.
Recommendations 1 and 2:

That clauses 6, 8 and 9 of the Bill be amended to reflect the discrimination against the aggrieved person as a member of a group, rather than as an individual, in accord with the principle suggested by Ms Hunter.
That consequential amendments should be made to clause 10.

As stated by officers of my Department in public hearings before the Committee, it was always intended that the new test for indirect discrimination, proposed in clauses 6, 8 and 9 of the Bill, would recognise that the "group element" is a central aspect of any definition of indirect discrimination.

However, in order to reduce any confusion and make absolutely clear what is intended, the Government accepts the majority's recommendation and will redraft the relevant clauses by way of Government amendments this session, in accordance with this recommendation.
Any necessary consequential amendments will be made to clause 10 of the Bill.
Recommendation 3:
That clause 10 should be amended to make clear that the proposed section 7D refers to equality of outcomes, provided that this can be achieved without causing undue delay.

As the Committee recognises, the proposed section 7D aims to protect measures that have, as one of their purposes, the aim of achieving "substantive equality". It always has been the Government's intention that section 7D refer to real or substantive equality.

I agree that the provision may not make this point as clearly as possible. The Government will therefore move an amendment to Clause 10 to clarify what is intended by inserting "substantive" before "equality" in section 7D. As noted by Ms Morgan (Submission No 18), "substantive equality" is synonymous with the idea of "equality of outcomes", but the Government's preference is to amend the provision to refer to substantive equality. This is more in keeping with the intended focus on achieving real equality.
Yours sincerely
MICHAEL LAVARCH

TALK.START.PARA: —I think a number of senators are having trouble hearing you.
—Mr Acting Deputy President, I am more concerned to get this into the Hansard than I am about the hearing of my colleagues. I can do no more than refer them to Hansard.

—As Hansard reporters have said in a couple of interviews, I am not the fastest speaker or reader in this parliament and I have no doubt they will be able to follow what I say. What they cannot follow, I am happy to give to them, because I am reading precisely from a transcript. I will continue:

SPEECH.PARA: No such ground has ever been ventured in respect to any member of the Liberal Party in Western Australia, never mind a senior Federal Senator, a past State President and a life member of State Council.
The State Executive motion asking me to resign gave no ground, justification or reason.

I was refused a right to attend that State Executive and to be heard. The resignation resolution by the State President to State Executive was based on different grounds to the expulsion motion. No grounds could or did justify the resignation motion. The expulsion motion was moved because quite naturally I would not simply bend to the misinformed, improper and biased call to resign.

The Presidents motives in moving the resignation and expulsion motions had nothing to do with the grounds, but were in part, the result of a deal he entered into with a small but threatening group of organisational and parliamentary members. Euphemistically called, on some occasions, "the peace plan".
The State President has deliberately ignored the debilitating, disruptive and destructive conduct and comments of a number of party members including senior office bearers and Members of Parliament.
One ground relates to the improper obtaining of private information and its improper distribution.

In respect to the restraining order, subsequent to its public disclosure, both the State President and the Premier have condemned its publication and stated frequently it should not and does not impinge upon my role or contribution as a Liberal Senator and both subsequently offered me publicly their full support.
Market research shows that the matter has had no impact whatsoever on voter intentions.

The action undertaken in respect to me is a gulf of difference between that of other contemporary Members of Parliament and the historic response to grave conduct by organisational and Parliamentary members.
The grounds contrived against me bear absolutely no comparison with examples which I have given.
The process undertaken by State Executive was based on an adversarial nature rather than one of ensuring proper and full opportunities for the matter to dealt with in a fair and conciliatory way.

My counsel and myself were invited to attend the State Executive, present our case and to answer a number of questions, but we were not entitled to ask questions, we were not able to rebut assertions made against me and nor were we able to rebut comments made in respect to our submission.

The public and private statements by the State President and other State Executive members prior to the State Executive meeting should have led to the disqualification of those from the hearing. However not withstanding a request from Malcolm McCusker QC that they disqualify themselves, they refused and participated in the deliberations.
1. RESTRAINING ORDER
The clauses of the State Executive resolution headed RESTRAINING ORDER AND PARTY LEADER are in breach of the Parliamentary Privileges Act 1987 which codifies article 9 of the Bill of Rights 1688[9].

The immunity of parliamentary proceedings from impeachment or question in courts or other tribunals depends ultimately on article 9 of the Bill of Rights of 1688 [9], which is part of the law applying to the Australian Houses by virtue of section 49 of the Constitution. Article 9 provided that "the freedom of speech and debates or proceedings in Parliament ought not to be impeached or questioned in any court or place out of Parliament".

Section 16 of the Parliamentary Privileges Act 1987 codifies the interpretation of article 9 in its application to the Australian Houses. The section provides that evidence of parliamentary proceedings cannot be used in any court or tribunal in any way contrary to article 9 or the section. The prohibited use of evidence of parliamentary proceedings is defined to include any use of those proceedings against any person in a wide sense.

While the Act provides a wide definition of "impeached or questioned", it does not exhaust the meaning of that phrase, and the definition of "tribunal" does not exhaust the category of bodies before which parliamentary proceedings must not be impeached or questioned. This is because section 16 provides that article 9 has the effect of the provisions of the section "in addition to any other operation".

The question is determined by the nature of the body, to its proceedings and of the detriment imposed on the member. The court would distinguish between mere withdrawal of political support, which obviously would not be unlawful, from anything in the nature of a penalty imposed on the member.
It should be noted that some procedures by which political parties impose Party discipline on their members may well be unlawful when imposed because of the members' activities in Parliament.
I draw your attention also to paragraphs (1), (2), and (4) of Resolution 6 of the Senate Privilege Resolutions setting out activities which may be treated as contempts:-
6.Matters constituting contempts
(1)A person shall not improperly interfere with the free exercise by the Senate or a committee of its authority, or with the free performance by a Senator of the Senator's duties as a Senator.

(2)A person shall not, by fraud, intimidation, force or threat of any kind, by the offer or promise of any inducement or benefit of any kind, or by other improper means, influence a Senator in the Senator's conduct as a Senator or induce a Senator to be absent from the Senate or a committee.
(4)A person shall not inflict any punishment, penalty or injury upon, or deprive of any benefit, a Senator on account of the Senator's conduct as a Senator.

This precludes most methods of Party discipline. I also draw your attention to Clause 16 ss3 (a) (b) (c) under section 7 of the Parliamentary Privileges Act 1987 (Cth). With regard to individuals, section 7 provides for maximum penalties of six months imprisonment (ss1) or a fine up to $5,000 (ss 5 (a)). Under this section corporations are subject to maximum fines of $25,000. (ss 5 (b)). It does not matter if the organisation is incorporated under Commonwealth or State legislation.

Clearly the Senate resolutions and the Parliamentary Privileges Act 1987 preclude items 1 & 2 of the resolution and therefore State Council will be in breach of these provisions if it considers them as grounds to support the resolution.

My view is confirmed by Harry Evans, Clerk of the Senate, considered internationally as the ultimate authority on matters of privilege. His opinion is supported and confirmed by the Hon Clive Griffiths MLC, President of the Legislative Council in Western Australia who is also acknowledged as a distinguished authority on privilege. Mr Griffiths is the longest serving Presiding Officer in the Commonwealth.
However for the purposes of further deliberations I set out the facts.
RESTRAINING ORDER [as set out in the State Executive Resolution]

PARA.EMPHASIS: This statement was made by me in the Senate against my strongest objections. It was demanded of me by the Liberal Parliamentary Leader John Howard with the support of Senator Robert Hill, the Leader of the Opposition in the Senate. Having been compelled to make a statement I drafted a short speech which gave considerably less concessions. This speech was unacceptable to John Howard as were two other versions. John Howard accepted a version to which Senator Hill made a significant contribution.

SPEECH.PARA: The Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 4) 1995 (the bill) will amend the taxation laws in a number of respects. It includes ten measures which give effect to announcements in the 1995-96 Budget.
The bill is mostly drafted in the new style emerging from the tax law improvement project. This will help taxpayers and their advisers in understanding the proposed changes.
The 1995-96 Budget included a number of measures relating to capital gains tax.
Amendments relating to value shifting

The bill proposes amendments to Division 19A of Part IIIA which operates to prevent the creation of capital losses, or reduction of capital gains realised on the disposal of shares or loans in a company. Losses can be created (or gains reduced) by shifting value out of the shares or loans through the transfer of assets to commonly owned companies for low or nil consideration. Where a value shift is taken to have occurred, the cost bases of shares and loans in the transferor company are reduced to reflect the transferred value. The proposed amendments will generally operate to reduce the costs for taxpayers in complying with Division 19A, and to rectify certain anomalies in its current operation.

Compliance costs will be reduced by enabling companies to transfer depreciable assets generally at their written down value without the need to make cost base adjustments provided that the market value of the assets is not substantially greater. Companies will also be able to group some assets that are transferred rather than deal with them on an asset by asset basis.

A simplified test will also be applied for assets acquired prior to the time at which the transferor and transferee companies came under common ownership. This measure will simplify the operation of the law, reduce uncertainty and thereby reduce compliance costs.

An anti avoidance measure is included in the bill so that Division 19A will apply to the creation and transfer of rights relating to an asset where the asset has not itself been transferred. Where the consideration for the transfer of the new asset is less than its market value, a value shift will be taken to have occurred.
This bill will also make a number of other technical amendments to Division 19A.
These amendments, which will have no significant impact on revenue, will apply to transfers of assets after 7.30pm AEST on 9 May 1995.
The bill increases the thresholds applicable to both listed and non-listed personal-use assets to $500 and $10,000 respectively.

The amendment to increase the thresholds for listed and non-listed personal-use assets will apply to disposals of assets occurring on or after 1 July 1995. The amendments will result in a cost to revenue of up to $2 million per year.

The bill will clarify the provisions relating to the disposal of certain taxable Australian assets. Some taxpayers have argued that gains on the disposal of taxable Australian assets used solely to produce franked dividends or income subject to withholding tax in Australia (such as certain shares in Australian companies and assets used in a permanent establishment in Australia) are not subject to capital gains tax.

This interpretation of the law is contrary to the clear intention of parliament. The amendments will ensure that capital gains tax will apply appropriately to disposals by non-residents of all taxable Australian assets and, thereby, will give effect to the intention underlying the existing law. They will apply to disposals of taxable Australian assets on or after 20 September 1985, which is the date from which capital gains tax applies.
The financial impact of this measure is unquantifiable.

The bill contains measures that will extend the existing capital gains tax relief which applies to a gain realised on the disposal of shares in a foreign company where the disposal also gives rise to a tax exempt non-portfolio dividend. The capital gain is reduced by the amount of the exempt dividend as though the dividend was taxable.
Currently, capital gains tax relief applies in relation to the disposal of shares in foreign companies which were created after 25 June 1992.

The bill proposes that capital gains tax relief will also be available in relation to disposals of shares in foreign companies where the shares were created before 26 June 1992. This measure will apply to disposals occurring from the 1990-91 year of income, which is the year from which the exemption provided for non-portfolio dividends also applies.

A related measure will ensure that disposals of shares which take place after 7.30pm AEST on 9 May 1995 and which give rise to non-portfolio dividends from foreign companies which are exempt from income tax, will only qualify for capital gains tax relief to the extent that the dividends are not paid out of a share capital account, share premium account or revaluation reserve of the foreign company. The bill also modifies the existing general capital gains tax relief which applies in relation to gains realised on the disposal of assets where a capital amount is expressly included (in whole or in part) in the assessable income of a taxpayer. The existing general capital gains tax relief will be modified to apply specifically to disposals of rights to receive eligible termination payments. The amendments will apply to disposals taking place after 7.30pm AEST on 9 May 1995.
The financial impact of these measures is unquantifiable.

The bill will provide that, where a company disposes of an asset to a related company and the disposal would give rise to a capital loss, a compulsory capital gains tax rollover will generally apply in relation to the transfer of the asset.
An exception is provided, subject to safeguards, where the company into which the loss asset is transferred is to be sold or floated within a specified time period.
These amendments will apply to transfers of assets between related companies taking place after 7.30pm AEST on 9 May 1995. They will prevent a potentially significant risk to revenue.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Amendment or replacement of trust deeds

SPEECH.PARA: The bill provides that a capital gains tax rollover will be available in relation to the disposal of the assets of a complying approved deposit fund (ADF) that would otherwise occur as a consequence of the conversion of the ADF to a complying superannuation fund. A rollover will also be available in relation to a disposal of the assets of an existing complying ADF or complying superannuation fund where the trust deed of the ADF or superannuation fund is amended or replaced in order to comply with the Superannuation Industry (Supervision) Act 1993.

The rollover will only be available where there is no change in the assets of the fund or interest of members in the fund as a consequence of the conversion of the ADF to a superannuation fund, or the amendment or replacement of the trust deed of the ADF or superannuation fund. This measure will apply to disposals of assets taking place on or after 12 January 1994, the date from which certain amendments to the CGT relating to settlements of trusts and transfers of property to trusts took effect.
The revenue impact of this proposal is insignificant.

The bill will amend the dividend imputation provisions as a result of the increase in the company tax rate from 33% to 36% with effect from the 1995-96 income year. The amendments, which will apply from 1 July 1995, will allow companies to record franking credits and debits and distribute imputation credits to shareholders by reference to tax paid at 36%. The value of existing 33% and 39% franking credits will be preserved for shareholders.
The amendments will reduce compliance costs for most companies because they will convert from the present dual franking account system to a single franking account.

The bill will also correct certain defects in the current dividend imputation provisions relating to life insurance companies. The amendments will apply from the time the defects in the current provisions first arose.One amendment will prevent an unintended gain to the revenue and the other amendment will prevent a significant potential loss to the revenue.

As part of the dividend imputation amendments, the bill also provides for the calculation of class C franking deficit tax and deficit deferral tax. These taxes are imposed by the Income Tax (Franking Deficit) Amendment Bill 1995 and the Income Tax (Deficit Deferral) Amendment Bill 1995 respectively. These separate bills are required for constitutional reasons.
In the 1995-96 Budget the government announced a measure to deny franking credits for profit shifting adjustments.

Under the current imputation system for company taxation, transfer pricing or non-arm's length dealing adjustments resulting in additional tax payable by an Australian resident company will give rise to a franking credit. This provision of a franking credit largely negates the additional tax payable by the resident company because the profits, which have been taxed under the transfer pricing and non-arm's length dealing adjustment provisions, have already been shifted or misallocated offshore and are not actually in Australia. Accordingly, the franking credits arising from the payment of the additional company tax assessed as a result of the transfer pricing adjustments can be used to frank profit distributions that would not otherwise be franked dividends and subject to the relevant tax relief measures.

The proposed amendment will ensure that the Australian revenue is not disadvantaged by international transfer pricing practices or non-arm's length dealings which misallocate or shift profits offshore.

The Treasurer announced in the 1995-96 Budget that specific taxation measures would be introduced for the demutualisation of mutual life and general insurance companies. These measures are proposed in this bill. The bill provides that a demutualisation may occur under a specified method and then describes the taxation consequences of certain transactions which may occur in the course of the demutualisation. All of the methods of demutualisation require that the interests of members in the mutual company will be extinguished in exchange for ordinary shares in the demutualised company.
The bill provides that capital gains tax will not apply to the surrender by a member of his or her membership interests in a mutual insurance company or a mutual affiliate company.

The bill establishes, for capital gains tax purposes, the date and cost of acquisition of shares acquired by former members as part of the demutualisation process. In relation to a life insurance company, the deemed acquisition cost of shares will be determined by reference to the embedded value of the company. For general insurance companies the deemed acquisition cost of shares will be determined by reference to the net tangible assets of the company.

No capital loss will be available in relation to the disposal of demutualisation shares and interests prior to the listing of ordinary shares in the demutualised entity. After listing, the deemed cost of acquisition of the shares will be the lesser of the amount calculated by reference to the embedded value or net tangible assets of the company and the last published price at which the demutualisation shares were traded on their first day of trading.The new provisions substantially relate to the application of the capital gains and losses provisions. However, parallel provisions have been included for transactions which would otherwise lead to amounts being included in the assessable income of a taxpayer.

The amendments will only apply to demutualisations of mutual companies that were in existence at 7.30pm AEST on 9 May 1995. The nature of the measure is such that the cost to revenue cannot be reliably estimated.

On 29 November 1994, the Treasurer and the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy announced that a form of taxation write-off would be extended to expenditure on new horticultural plantations. The details of the form of write-off were announced on 9 May 1995 as part of the 1995-96 budget.
The purpose of the amendments is to give capital expenditure on horticultural plantations such as orchards and perennial crops comparable tax treatment to capital expenditure in other industries.

The bill allows taxpayers to write off the original capital expenditure incurred in establishing horticultural plants which are used, or are held ready for use, by taxpayers to produce assessable income in businesses of horticulture. The period over which the expenditure is written off will be based on the effective life of the plants, and gives the same rate of deduction as prime cost (or `straight line') depreciation of plant and equipment with the same effective life. Where effective life is less than three years there is an immediate write-off for establishment expenditure to the first taxpayer to use the plant, or hold it ready for use, to produce assessable income from a business of horticulture.
There is expected to be a cost to revenue of $1 million in 1997-98, $2 million in 1998-99 and $4 million in 1999-2000.
The bill will give effect to the measures announced in the 1995-96 Budget relating to immature forests and plantations.

This measure is designed to overcome an anomaly that exists in some circumstances where an established but immature plantation or forest is purchased by a taxpayer engaged in forestry operations, and subsequently sold with the timber still standing. This taxpayer may be taxed on the gross value of the standing timber rather than the net profit.

The measure provides that where a taxpayer, who is engaged in timber operations and has purchased an established but immature plantation or forest, sells that plantation or forest after 9 May 1995 outside the normal course of business the taxpayer is assessed on the net profit from the sale.
The bill also contains certain anti-avoidance provisions relating to non arm's length transactions.
There is expected to be a cost to revenue of $1 million in 1995-96 and $4 million in subsequent years.

In the 1995-96 Budget the government announced a measure to deny a deduction for expenditure on research and development activities incurred to a private tax exempt body where that expenditure is not fully at risk.

Where a company incurs expenditure in relation to research and development activities carried out on its behalf, the arrangements are often structured in such a way that the company receives a guaranteed return for its expenditure.

When expenditure is incurred to a tax exempt body, that body faces no tax liability on its income. Therefore the arrangement may support higher guaranteed returns than an arrangement in which expenditure is incurred to a taxpayer. In effect, the Commonwealth is funding the higher guaranteed return. The company owning the research will derive a tax benefit because of the tax exempt status of the researcher.

This bill gives effect to the government's 1995-96 Budget announcement that new rules will be introduced to limit the circumstances in which trusts can deduct current year and prior year losses.
The government is making these changes to stop the significant erosion of revenue that has been occurring through trafficking in trust losses.

The tax law already contains tests which limit the deductibility of losses incurred by companies. The proposed rules that are to apply to trusts will differ in some respects from those that apply to companies, reflecting the different characteristics of trusts. The government has been concerned to ensure that the law operates fairly and has therefore decided that the tests to be satisfied before losses are deductible will vary depending on the type of trust.
For example, family trusts will generally be able to deduct losses, provided that members of the same family are the only persons who could benefit from the trust.
Special rules will also apply to widely held listed unit trusts. These rules will help to minimise compliance costs for this type of trust.

While fixed trusts will be subject to a continuity of ownership test, non family discretionary trusts will be subject to continuity of ownership, continuity of control and pattern of distribution tests. This reflects the fact that it is not possible to apply the same beneficial ownership test to discretionary trusts.
Trusts (including family trusts) will be subject to an income injection test to ensure generally that trust losses are not used by outsiders to shelter their income from tax.

Exceptions from these measures are provided for complying superannuation funds, complying approved deposit funds and pooled superannuation trusts. The measures will also not apply to deceased estates for a reasonable period of administration.

The proposed rules designed to prevent trafficking in trust losses necessarily reflect the complex nature of the different types of trusts. The amendments are therefore lengthy but, as already indicated, they are designed to ensure fairness in the system.

The drafting approach for these amendments follows the new tax law improvement style and the structure follows that of the redrafted company loss provisions which are due to be introduced into Parliament later this year.
The estimated gain to revenue from the proposed changes is $90 million in 1995-96, $185 million in 1996-97, $155 million in 1997-98 and $65 million in 1998-99.

Also included in this bill is a measure to give effect to the 1995-96 Budget announcement to transfer responsibility for the maintenance of the Register of Approved Occupational Clothing from the Textiles, Clothing and Footwear Development Authority to AusIndustry in the Department of Industry, Science and Technology.
This amendment has no effect on revenue.
Full details of the measures in the bills are contained in the explanatory memorandum circulated to honourable senators.
I commend the bill to the Senate.
