SPEECH.PARA: STATES GRANTS (PRIMARY AND SECONDARY EDUCATION ASSISTANCE) AMENDMENT BILL (No. 2) 1995

This bill amends the States Grants (Primary And Secondary Education Assistance) Act 1992 to give effect to initiatives announced in the 1995-96 budget and to provide for cost supplementation of grants for 1995 and 1996 in accordance with established policy.

The bill proposes an extension of the early literacy program to 1996. This program provides grants to foster literacy development for children in the early years of schooling. Some $6.666 million is to be made available to government schools and $2.208 million to non-government schools in the year. As in 1995, there will be special emphasis on children disadvantaged by low socio-economic circumstances.

Another budget initiative reflected in the bill is a proposal for a new program of grants to non-government special schools to assist students with disabilities to make the transition to mainstream school education or pursue further training or employment. An amount of $3.22 million is to be provided in 1996.

The final budget decision reflected in the bill is the cessation of new projects in 1996 under the gender equity program, the gifted and talented children program and for staff training, development and community liaison under the hostels for rural school students program. These initiatives have either served their purpose or are now more appropriately the responsibility of other bodies.

The bill also provides for supplementation of capital and recurrent grants to reflect movements in costs. For 1995 this means an additional $7 million for capital purposes and $55 million for recurrent programs, and for 1996 an additional $56 million for recurrent programs and a further $7 million for capital programs.
I commend the bill to the Senate.
BOUNTY LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL 1995

This bill is an omnibus measure proposing the validation of certain Ministerial declarations and the amendment of three Bounty Acts; namely, the Bounty (Computers) Act 1984 (the Computer Bounty Act), the Bounty (Machine Tools and Robots) Act 1985 (the Machine Tools and Robots Act) and the Bounty (Fuel Ethanol) Act 1994 (the Fuel Ethanol Act).

There are three major elements proposed in this bill. The first relates to the validation of certain untabled Ministerial declarations made under the Computer Bounty Act and the Machine Tools and Robots Act. The non-tabling of these declarations was discovered as a result of an investigation into the status of all legal instruments administered by the Department of Industry, Science and Technology that was instigated by the Minister for Industry, Science and Technology after the discovery of a similar administrative oversight in relation to guidelines under the Industry Research and Development Act 1986. The Minister made a statement in the Senate on 26 June 1995 concerning the bounty legislation problem and the validation element of this bill is designed to address that issue.

Both the Computer Bounty Act and the Machine Tools and Robots Act have a declaration facility by which the Minister can vary the classes of equipment eligible for bounty so that new technologies can be brought into the schemes as they arise. The facility is designed to allow the schemes to cater for the rapid technological advances which are a feature of these industry sectors. In order to maintain Parliamentary scrutiny of the classes of equipment eligible for bounty, the Ministerial declarations are subject to the same tabling and disallowance procedures applicable to other forms of subsidiary legislation by the express application of section 48 of the Acts Interpretation Act 1901.

The failure to table 20 declarations under the Computer Bounty Act and a further 12 under the Machine Tools and Robots Act has resulted in each declaration being invalidated after 15 sitting days of its making. A consequence of the legal invalidity of the declarations is that all decisions and acts or things done in reliance on those declarations (including applications claiming bounty, assessments of claims and decisions to pay or refuse bounty), are also invalid.

Clauses 5 and 6 of the bill propose to address the invalidity problems by validating the declarations, and any decisions made, or acts or things done, in reliance on those declarations, from the time of their commencement as notified in the Gazette, until the Royal Assent commencement of this bill.

Clause 7 of the bill expressly extinguishes the Commonwealth's right to recover any amounts paid on the production of goods purportedly made bountiable under the declaration facility of both acts. This will overcome the situation of Commonwealth officers having a duty to recover what have become unauthorised payments out of Consolidated Revenue and is appropriate given the fact that the various payments that have been made in reliance on the declarations over the years were always intended to be made.

The second element of the bill involves the incorporation of the effect of the 3 valid current declarations into the Computer Bounty Act and the Machine Tools and Robots Act. Schedules 2 and 3 to the bill incorporate into each of the acts the various classes of goods which are presently bountiable via the declaration facility.

The goods to be inserted under the relevant definitions of "bountiable equipment" have been the subject of new declarations Gazetted in August and September 1995 and have been tabled in each House of Parliament as required of section 48 of the Acts Interpretation Act 1901. These 3 declarations remade the effect of 7 of the invalid declarations and were made so that bounty payments relating to claims on hand could be processed during the time between the discovery of the invalidity and the passage of this validating bill. The remaining invalid declarations were not remade as their effect had already been incorporated into the Principal acts by various Bounty Legislation Amendment Bills or they had become redundant because the technology to which they related has been superseded.

The incorporation of the effect of these current valid declarations into the Principal acts is intended to bring all the goods which are currently eligible for bounty under the one piece of principal legislation, as opposed to a mixture of Legislation plus disparate declarations. I consider that periodically incorporating future declarations into the Principal acts will also help to ensure their legal correctness and legal drafting in a way that has not always been the case in the past. This should obviate the need for repeating this exercise in the future by better aligning the declaration facility with the express parliamentary controls in the legislation.

The final element of the bill implements the Government's 1995-96 Budget decision in relation to the Fuel Ethanol Act. The Fuel Ethanol Act gives effect to a scheme to assist in the development of a competitive, robust and ecologically sustainable fuel ethanol industry. The three year scheme, which commenced on 1 July 1994, provides for the payment of a bounty of 18 cents for each litre of fuel ethanol produced, providing certain criteria are met. One of these criteria is that bounty should only be paid on `new production' of fuel ethanol, which effectively imposed an extra production requirement on pre-1 July 1994 producers by only making bountiable that production in excess of the average of fuel ethanol produced in 1992 and 1993.

The amendments to the eligibility criteria under the Fuel Ethanol Act in Schedule 1 to the bill are to give effect to the 1995 Budget decision to ensure all eligible fuel ethanol producers can claim bounty on the same production criteria, irrespective of whether they were engaged in production prior to the 1 July 1994 commencement of the Fuel Ethanol Act.
The financial implications of the measures proposed in the bill are as follows:
(i) Computer Bounty Act and Machine Tools and Robots Act

the validation of Ministerial declarations made under each of these acts will preserve the legal effectiveness of monies already paid out under the relevant declarations since the commencement of each act. The amendments will not result, however, in any additional outlays.
(ii) Fuel Ethanol Act

the amendments to the eligibility criteria under the Fuel Ethanol Act are expected to cost $1 million in total over the 3 year life of the bounty (ie 1 July 1994 to 30 June 1997). However, that additional cost is to be accommodated within the current legislative allocation for the bounty.
I commend the bill to the Senate and present the explanatory memorandum to this bill.

TALK.START.PARA: —Last week the advocates of Queensland's largest meat processors launched a scathing attack on the Australian Industrial Relations Commission, the Minister for Industrial Relations (Mr Brereton) and the Australian Meat Industry Employees Union. AMH has viciously attacked the commission for challenging its rights to threaten and intimidate its workers in its bid to drive down wages and conditions in Queensland.

PARA.TAB: A fortnight ago a question was raised in the House of Representatives concerning the Rockhampton plant of Australia Meat Holdings and some rather dubious industrial tactics used by the employers to achieve non-union enterprise flexibility agreements. Mr Brereton revealed that AMH used a good deal of outside assistance and outside influence at its Rockhampton plant to persuade workers to accept the EFA. The minister revealed that Mr Bruce Townsend and a team of 14 people had been secretly employed to act as agents provocateurs and to bust the AMIEU in Queensland.

Information has been provided to me that Mr Bruce Studley Townsend has been employed as a strikebreaker by Mr Keith Lawson, managing director of AMH, Mr Les Parker, manager of the Rockhampton Meatworks, and Mr John Hughes, a senior industrial officer at AMH. I am informed that up to 15 strikebreakers have been employed at $800 per week cash in hand and that Mr Townsend himself has received $3,000 per week cash in hand. Mr Townsend was paid by the Ipswich office of AMH. Mr Townsend's duties included phone tapping union members, videotaping union meetings through the boot of a car, intimidating workers, and persuading workers to cross picket lines.

Given the voracity of Mr Townsend and his team for taping and recording, it might not be surprising to learn that the arbitration commission has moved its hearings from the plant to the local courthouse. Other members of Mr Townsend's Rockhampton team include an ex-prison officer and an ex-police officer. It seems that the job of these people is to act as heavies and to persuade people involved in the industrial dispute at the Rockhampton plant with violence if necessary.

Mr Bruce Townsend is a resident of Tasmania and is managing director of the firm Australian Security and Investigation. He is registered in Tasmania as a licensed security agent and process server. However, Mr Townsend has a long record of strikebreaking in Tasmania, such as at APM, and he is well known to the timberworkers' union. He has also appeared previously in Queensland where he worked with Mr Graham Haycroft of Troubleshooters Available.

Troubleshooters Available has also specialised in strikebreaking in Tasmania and Victoria, mainly in the building industry but in the meat industry as well. Troubleshooters Available supplied unskilled contract labour for the Camperdown abattoir in Victoria some four years ago, enabling the employers to lock out the local meatworkers who were members of the union and who were not prepared to work for wages and conditions well below the award.

Mr Townsend says he is a consultant and is not registered to operate in Queensland as an investigator or as a security agent. He says his main function at the Rockhampton meatworks is to `advise on enterprise bargaining agreements and prepare precedence reports'. This, of course, reflects the growing trend within AMH towards the Americanisation of its industrial relations. This is brought about by the employment of strikebreakers and union busters. Mr Townsend is no ordinary worker. His job is clearly to antagonise and intimidate union members. The company, AMH, provides strikebreakers with false payroll slips to make them look like genuine workers.

Mr Townsend was engaged by senior management of Conagra in Queensland who happen to be closely identified with the Liberal Party in that state. In other words, senior Liberal Party members have been directly involved in these unseemly events. Senior Liberal Party figures also figured during the meatworkers' dispute at Camperdown in Victoria during 1991-92. The local meatworkers set up a picket line outside the Camperdown abattoir and an agent provocateur appeared on the scene. His name was Warwick Leeson. He employed rather crude tactics of verbal abuse, throwing rocks and eggs at picketers, and even driving his car into one of the unionists. Later, some of his associates were involved in even more violent acts including the bashing of three unionists with shovels and iron bars.

Mr Leeson, a private investigator, was hired by the law firm of Kroger and Kroger to gather information for a damages action against the AMIEU. Leeson had to provoke and try and incite violence and disruption by the picketers in order to make a case for Kroger and Kroger in its prosecution of the AMIEU. At that time Mr Kroger was president of the Victorian branch of the Liberal Party and a long-time associate of Mr Costello, the current Deputy Leader of the Liberal Party.

Mr Warwick Leeson was himself a Liberal Party member and in fact served as a branch president. It is widely rumoured that Mr Michael Kroger first used Mr Leeson's sleazy investigative techniques to dig up dirt on the wets or moderates in Victoria during the great purge of the Liberal Party under Mr Kroger's presidency. Mr Kroger, along with several senior Liberal Party members of parliament, attended an hysterical meeting at the Camperdown race track in support of the anti-union contractors.

Mr Kroger and Mr Costello have long shared a vision of a brave new world of industrial relations—one where workers would have no organised representation and where employers can determine wages and conditions at whim. Powerless workers have two choices: take it or have no job. They talk about negotiation and cooperation but, in reality, we have the Warwick Leesons and the Bruce Townsends running around with tape-recorders, with rotten eggs, and even with weapons, to coerce, intimidate and frighten workers into submission.

Is this the sort of industrial relations the Liberal Party stands for? Is this the sort of thuggery they are prepared to tolerate: stooges paid by employers to bust up union meetings, hired guns used to get contractors in place to reduce wages and conditions? As Minister Brereton has made clear, there is no place in Australian industrial relations for professional strike breakers and secret surveillance and the taping of picket lines, union meetings or anything else. A Labor government in my view remains committed to ensuring that enterprise bargaining is pursued in an environment free from coercion.

PARA.TAB: Hepatitis C is a blood borne virus affecting up to 200,000 Australians. It is estimated that up to 9,000 people are newly affected each year. Eighty per cent of those exposed to the virus will become carriers, 25 per cent will develop chronic liver disease and up to 10 per cent will die as a result. The virus attacks the liver and over the past year it has become the most common cause for liver transplants. There are many unknowns about hepatitis C and that is why I raised it with Senator Crowley a couple of weeks ago. Drug users and former drug addicts could be unknown carriers. It is speculated that tattoos and body piercing, or even the shared use of razors or toothbrushes, may contribute to the spread of the virus.

Education is very important. I understand that guidelines for GPs and others will be published shortly in line with the strategy that was drawn up over a year ago. This $4 million that has been spent compares very unfavourably with funding for other medical programs. Just for interest, over the next two years $110 million has been earmarked for HIV and AIDS research.

The low priority given by the government demonstrates that the government simply is not serious about or does not understand the hepatitis C crisis we are facing. It is a matter of urgency. The government has not allocated enough of its resources or time to education programs or giving sufferers access to treatment they need. I understand that the drug interferon alpha 2B is the only treatment available for hepatitis C, and each day sees the queues for interferon growing larger—as with the queues of people waiting to have their conditions assessed. Interferon has been subsidised by the federal government since 1 October 1994, but I understand that the states and territories cannot comply with a national action plan because of funding constraints from the federal government. An expert on hepatitis, Professor Geoff Farrell, was quoted in the Australian of 21 October as saying:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . the major single problem for hepatitis C patients at the moment is getting access to services where they can get appropriate counselling and treatment.

Professor Farrell went on to say that the virus, which was discovered in 1989, had progressed more rapidly than anticipated, with liver cancer at least doubling over the past decade, largely because of the virus.

PARA.TAB: The government must review the situation immediately and address a problem which, left unchecked, will cost the public health system hundreds of millions of dollars a year and will cause many more deaths than are necessary.

TALK.START.PARA: —Frequent changes to both tax and superannuation law are confusing, not only to the public but also to the experts who are obliged to keep up with all the amendments passed by this parliament. A good example was a recent case in the Federal Court of Australia. The Queensland Registry, General Division, was called upon to adjudicate between the Insurance and Superannuation Commission, the applicant, and Wayne Cyril Hiscock, as trustee for Osborne Fruit Drinks Superannuation Fund, the respondent. The judgment highlights the complex process of present day law making. This case illustrates very vividly that, if administrative decision makers such as the Administrative Appeals Tribunal find it hard to know the law as expressed by the parliament, it must be even harder for the trustees and their advisers.

PARA.TAB: The case before the Administrative Appeals Tribunal was a provision of the Occupational Superannuation Standards Act of 1987—which has now been superseded by the Superannuation Industry (Supervision) Act—as it stood following an amendment which had not been drawn to the attention of the tribunal. Relevant provisions were section 12(3A) of the act and section 49 of the Taxation Laws Amendment (Superannuation) Act 1993. These provisions deal with the ISC's discretion regarding a breach of, in this case, the in-house assets rule.The intent of section 49 was to limit the discretion available to the ISC. The fund in question was affected only if section 49 was found to have a retrospective effect.

Section 7(2H) of the Occupational Superannuation Standards Act provides that standards may be prescribed with respect to investment of assets of superannuation funds. If there is compliance with those standards, the trustees of the fund receive a notice from the Insurance and Superannuation Commissioner under section 12 which entitles the fund to concessional rates of taxation, which are currently to a maximum of 15 per cent.

The problem for the Osborne Fruit Drinks superannuation fund was that it did not comply with those standards during the income year ended 30 June 1991. The trustee sought the exercise of the commissioner's discretion under section 13(1) of the act, which provided that trustees might satisfy the commissioner that because of special circumstances that existed it was reasonable for the commissioner to treat the fund as if it had satisfied those standards.

Before coming to its decision, the court noted that section 12(3A) had been inserted by an amending act, No. 92 of 1992, taking effect on 1 July 1992. That provided that, in the making of a decision under section 12(3) as to whether a fund satisfied the conditions, the commissioner was obliged to disregard a breach of the superannuation fund if certain conditions were present. The reference to a breach was not further qualified as to its nature or as to the time when it was to have occurred.

Later on 24 October 1994 the Administrative Appeals Tribunal substituted a decision. The fund satisfied the conditions in relation to the income year ended 30 June 1991. It did so by applying the provisions of section 12(3A), which, as it observed, were not in force during 1991 but were in force when the delegate's decision was made, and held that the section was to be applied by the tribunal. It noted in particular that there were no transitional provisions relating to the amendment in question and nothing else to suggest that its ordinary meaning could not be given effect to. That is, it was to be applied when a decision was made after 1 July 1992.

It was indeed unfortunate that the tribunal's attention was not drawn to a particular subsection that had been the subject of a further statutory provision. Those amendments took effect on 30 July 1993 and, more specifically, by the provision of section 49 of act No. 7 of 1993 entitled `Transitional' which came into effect on 27 May 1993. The Hon. Justice Kiefel said:

SPEECH.PARA: What it seems to me then the Tribunal, not properly informed, fell into a legal error in applying the provisions of section 12(3a). There does remain the question as to the application of section 13(1) of the 1987 Act.
He further stated that it was that provision upon which the delegate's decision was originally based and that its application was argued before the tribunal.

PARA.TAB: The second issue that I wish to raise in the Senate tonight concerns an overview of the 1985 tax summit. That overview was provided by an eminent practitioner, Mr Richard Buchanan, a former president of the Tax Institute of Australia and a current partner of KPMG in Melbourne. He presented a paper to the University of New South Wales entitled `ATAX Tax Summit' on 20 September this year. The thrust of Mr Buchanan's speech was that, while the income tax system may generally be fairer, there was a significant increase in the additional cost of compliance and complexity.

Mr Buchanan states that, while the 1985 summit was intended to benefit the Australian people, there were a number of goals at that summit that were not achieved. He said that the system was still biased against the honest, the productive, the worker and the saver. More importantly, he said that the system was biased against the exporter and the home producer. It is this bias which costs Australian jobs, Australian investment and Australian exports. Australia has paid and continues to pay a very high price for this. One of the aims of the 1985 summit was to attack the black economy. However, after scrapping option C—the consumption tax—little has been achieved in overcoming the problems of the black economy, and both cash and barter transactions continue to thrive.

The percentage of total federal taxation revenue—that is, individual income tax—raised 55 per cent in 1984-85. Ten years later, if FBT is included, it raises 54.9 per cent, which effectively means that there has been no change. However, in that time the burden on Australian taxpayers, particularly business taxpayers, to collect and account for tax has placed a significant hidden cost on those businesses. For example, the income tax legislation has become a lot weightier. John Howard referred to this when responding to the budget earlier this year. The CCH published act in 1985 weighed 2.1 kilos, whereas it now weighs 5.1 kilos. It does point out, however, that whilst the Australian taxation system over 10 years may be a lot fairer it is certainly a lot costlier for business to comply with. While the change to introduce the imputation system of taxation of corporate profits was a material and worthwhile change, it did not shift the emphasis and reliance on the taxation of savings to consumption, and consumption remains a relatively lowly tax by comparison with savings.

Mr Buchanan, of course, does draw on research undertaken by Mr Phillip Holt, who is the Chief Executive of the Chamber of Manufactures of New South Wales. Mr Phillip Holt indicates that, if indirect taxes could be removed from the costs of exports, Australia could boost exports by $3.9 billion by the year 2000, as our products would be more competitive on world markets.

I raise these matters of general interest in this debate because I believe that the cost of compliance and the uncertainty of the legislation is becoming a very significant issue in our tax law. Therefore, I ask: what chance does the ordinary John or Mary Citizen have of understanding and complying with this act when the experts cannot get it right and when the costs of compliance are just so high?

TALK.START.PARA: —On this evening of 12 November 1995, I rise to mark the fourth anniversary of the Dili massacre. Yesterday I attended a memorial service at All Saints Chapel in Perth, Western Australia, to commemorate the event. I must say that the rally which took place afterwards was a credit to the people who organised it. There were those who felt, and feel, quite emotional about this matter—and quite understandably so. They had called upon the organisers to burn an Indonesian flag, and I note that they exercised constraint in not doing so. For that, I compliment them because I do believe that a good deal can be achieved by constructive criticism and constructive debate.

PARA.TAB: I was in Lisbon earlier this year when there was an international conference on the question of East Timor, and I believe that there was constructive debate at that conference. Shortly after that there was in Austria, I understand, a meeting between most of the parties concerned—and, hopefully, something will come of this.

But I do note, with great disappointment, that the Indonesian authorities refused admission into East Timor to a group of international observers. One was Senator David Norris from Ireland, whom I met at the conference I mentioned previously; another was Bishop Soma, a Catholic bishop of Japan; and another was an Anglican minister, Ann Baten, of New Zealand. I also note that in that group there was Mr Paul Stewart, an Australian musician and the brother of a journalist who was killed in East Timor some 20 years ago; he also wanted to go to East Timor to mark the anniversary of the Dili massacre.

I can only say that, when protesters exercise the constraint that these did, the Indonesian authorities do not advance matters by refusing the admission of such international observers. As I say, I have met Senator David Norris from Ireland. He is not, I believe, a security risk. He is not the sort of person who would go around making trouble. I can only urge the Indonesian authorities to open up East Timor so that people of this sort, of this standing, can visit East Timor and that perhaps some progress can be made in resolving the problem there.

I notice that the Pacific Conference of Catholic Archbishops expressed a great deal of concern about the interference there is with the freedom to practise the Catholic religion in East Timor by East Timorese people and, indeed, the freedom to speak their own language and to engage in their own culture. Any such restraint must be the subject of great criticism by Australia. This is something which is happening on our doorstep, several hundred kilometres from the northern border of the state which I represent. This sort of action and the actions of disallowing the people that I have mentioned entrance into East Timor on the occasion of this anniversary does not do anything to advance the resolution of this matter.

The proposal by Indonesia to have Mr Mantiri act as that country's ambassador was met with widespread criticism. I can only say that I commend the Indonesian government for its decision not to push through with that decision because to do so would have been a highly provocative act. I am pleased to see that was not done.

We have a strong relationship with Indonesia, thankfully so, but when friends have a difference of opinion they express that in a very frank manner and they do not hold back. They can talk freely with each other because that is the basis of any strong relationship, of any relationship based on friendship. Therefore, I take it that the Indonesian authorities will not take what I say the wrong way and, hopefully, will look at it in a constructive manner and appreciate that, in my state in Western Australia, the people who attended that rally did so with a good deal of constraint and that they specifically took measures to avoid offending the Indonesian government by the burning of that country's flag.

In return, I ask the Indonesian authorities to behave similarly and to appreciate that there are people who have an interest in the matter in East Timor and that there are East Timorese who certainly would like a more open approach to this problem. I have couched my address today in rather restrained terms because I believe that adopting a radical stance does not achieve anything.

Earlier today we moved a condolence motion for the death of Yitzhak Rabin. We heard in this very chamber how he had expressed that the killing had to stop, that the time for war was over and that constructive measures were needed if a peaceful resolution was to be obtained in the Middle East. I would put to the Senate that the situation in East Timor is the same. It is a situation where radical measures on either side will not help, but firm constructive dialogue and action will succeed.

I recall the motion that was moved by His Honour Mr Justice Michael Kirby at the conference in Lisbon whereby he set out some specific steps which could be taken to promote a resolution in East Timor. I commend those steps. One of them was to open up East Timor more to visits by members of foreign parliaments and to increase the presence of bodies like the Red Cross. I can see no prejudice to the Indonesian authorities in allowing this. I can see no breach in security in allowing this. I can only question what their motives must be in such an over-reaction in not allowing people of the sort I have described admission into East Timor.

Therefore, I bring to the Senate's attention, on the fourth anniversary of the Dili massacre, the unfortunate actions which occurred. We must not forget that that was a situation which involved the death of unarmed civilians in a non-violent demonstration—deaths which were caused by the military. This is not denied by the Indonesian authorities, which they themselves commissioned an inquiry into.

I think it is appropriate that, whilst we work towards strengthening our ties with Indonesia, we do not forget things such as the Dili massacre, we do not forget the deaths of the Australian journalists concerned. To do otherwise would be a sham. It would be an affront to any strengthening of the relationship with Indonesia. This is a matter which should be addressed front on and discussed frankly with the Indonesia authorities.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Industry, Science and Technology, upon notice, on 6 July 1995:

PARA.TAB: With reference to the recent transport of radioactive waste from the Australian Defence Industries' St Mary's site to Woomera Rangehead:

(1)(a) Did the report Transport of Certain Radioactive Waste Material from Sydney to Interim Storage at Woomera Rangehead contain on page 1 a table entitled `Relative doses from some radiation related activities'; (b) was this table prepared by the Australian Nuclear Science and Technology Organisation: if so by whom and according to what principles: and (c) why does this table not contain actual units of radiation.

(2)(a) Did this table provide what it called relative doses according to which, the dose received by standing for one hour at a distance of two metres from a freight container full of St Marys waste, was the same as that from a return flight from Los Angeles, and the same as 18 days of background radiation; and (b) does this mean that the dose received by a person standing two metres from a container will be 18 days by 24 hours, that is, 432 times background radiation.

(3) Does this mean that someone such as a truck driver who was at a distance of two metres from a container of such waste for the full duration of a trip to Woomera would receive the equivalent of approximately a years worth of background radiation (or 20 chest x-rays, or 24 flights from Sydney to Los Angeles) depending on the precise length of the trip and the shielding factor of the International Standards Organisation containers.

(4) If the figure of 20 microsieverts for dose rates in the truck cab supplied by the Department of Defence notice of intent is correct, does 20 millisievert per hour come to approximately 100 x 7 times natural background radiation of 0.23 mSv's and nearly 300 times approximately 0.06 mSv's per hour gamma component.

(5)(a) How do the relative doses in this table relate to statements in the Department of Defence's notice of proposal that the dose rate at the outside of the shipping containers would be less than 1 000 microsieverts per hour (that is 1 mSv per hour) and that the dose to drivers would be less than 20 mSv's; (b) why is there a 50 to 1 difference between the radiation intensity at the container surface and in the truck cab; and (c) is the figure of 20 microsieverts per hour based on actual measurement or guesswork.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1)(a) Yes.

(b) Yes. The table was prepared by one of ANSTO's senior scientists. The information in it is based on published data, principally from the document `Sources and Effects of Ionising Radiation', published in 1993 by the United Nations Scientific Committee on the Effects of Atomic Radiation, and the limits under the Australian Code of Practice for the Safe Transport of Radioactive Substances 1990. The Australian Radiation Laboratory was consulted in the course of the preparation of the table and is in agreement with the data in it.

(c) The purpose of the table was to explain to members of the public how doses that might be received by people in proximity of the waste compared with doses from other activities. The doses were not specified in microsieverts because that would have added nothing to the explanation.
(2)(a) Yes.

(b) The question is unclear. If Senator Margetts' question relates to a person standing two metres from a container for 18 days, then the data in the table means that the dose would have been 432 times one hour's background radiation dose. This amounts to about 100 microsieverts, or 5 per cent of the annual dose from background radiation.

(3) No. When the trucks were loaded, the drivers' cabins were about six metres in front of the freight containers and the packages of waste were positioned inside the containers in such a way as to minimise the dose rates in the cabins. Moreover, new drivers took over about half way through the trip. There were only very brief opportunities for anyone to stand at a distance of two metres from a container during the journey.

(4) The figure of 20 microsieverts per hour in the Department of Defence's Notice of Intention (NOI) for dose rates in truck cabins was an estimate, based on the information available at the time the NOI was prepared. In the event, the measured dose rates in truck cabins during the trip to the Rangehead were much lower.

(5)(a) The actual doses from the activities listed in the table can be obtained by multiplying the relative doses by 100 microsieverts. Thus, the dose rate at the surface of the container is derived from the table as 10x100 microsieverts per hour, which equates to 1,000 microsieverts per hour as stated in the NOI. The data in the table do not refer to the dose to drivers.
(b) Radiation intensity decreases rapidly with distance and can be further reduced by placement of shielding, as happened in this case.
(c) Neither. The figure was an estimate, based on the information available at the time the NOI was prepared.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Transport, upon notice, on 23 August 1995:

PARA.TAB: (1) What is the status of the Federal Airports Corporation's Terminal 21 plan.
(2) What was the capacity of Sydney Airport using only the pre-existing east-west and north-south runways.
(3) What is the current capacity of Sydney Airport using the two parallel north-south runways.
(4) What are the forecasts for this capacity to increase in the years ahead.
(5) Has the Federal Government set a limit to the aircraft capacity at Sydney Airport.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Transport has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: The Federal Airports Corporation (FAC) and Airservices Australia has provided the following advice:

(1) "Terminal 21" was a generic title used for the FAC study group tasked with assessing demand on international facilities at the airport before the year 2000. The particular scheme which appeared in the media was one of a series of concepts which had been developed to establish aircraft parking options. None of these concepts has any official FAC status.

(2) The 1991 Environmental Impact Statement (EIS) stated that the practical cross runway capacity was 221,000 movements per annum, calculated on an overall average delay of 4 minutes. This is a criterion widely used internationally, and is the average delay beyond which maximum delays during peak periods become unacceptable to passengers.
The EIS also referred to a maximum hourly movement rate of 52 when using the two original runways without Simultaneous Operations (SIMOPS).

(3) Current monthly movements at Sydney Airport are approximately 22,000, which equates to slightly more than 260,000 movements per annum. The airport is currently achieving, using parallel runways, a busy hour maximum of 65 movements, moving to 80-85 movements per hour when the control tower and associated infrastructure is commissioned. It is projected that on current Department of Transport forecast traffic growth rates, by the year 2000 annual aircraft movements at Sydney Airport would be approximately 290,000.
(4) See answer to question 3.
(5) As stated in the EIS for the parallel runway, the ultimate practical capacity of the airport has been estimated at 353,000 aircraft movements per year based on a 4 minute annual average delay.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Transport, upon notice, on 4 September 1995:

PARA.TAB: (1) How many investigations are being conducted into the Iron Baron oil spill.
(2) Are these investigations looking into the grounding of the tanker; if so, will there be any examination of why and how it happened.

(3) Are these investigations looking into the effects of the spill; if so, are they going to investigate the extent of environmental damage and detail the total cost of clean up for all bodies concerned.
(4) Can the terms of reference for the inquiries be provided.
(5) Is the Australian Maritime Safety Authority (AMSA) conducting any of the inquiries.
(6) What is AMSA's role in the management of the Iron Baron spill.
(7) What is AMSA's responsibility in the ongoing management of oil spills and long-term damage minimisation and control.
(8) (a) Who is responsible for the National Oil Spill Management plan; and (b) who implements this plan.
(9) If AMSA is not conducting any inquiry, is it, or are any of its employees, involved in a chairing, organising or staffing capacity with any inquiry.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Transport has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) Two.

(2) Yes. An investigation under the Navigation Act 1912 by the Inspector of Marine Accidents, Department of Transport, is being undertaken to identify the circumstances and determine the cause of the grounding of the vessel.

(3) Yes. A review under the National Plan to Combat Pollution of the Sea by Oil (the National Plan), will examine the effects of the spill as part of its assessment of the response. Calculation of the total costs for all bodies concerned is not part of this review.

(4) There are no specific terms of reference for the inquiry being conducted by the Inspector of Marine Accidents. The Navigation (Marine Casualty) Regulations, made pursuant to section 425(1)(EA) of the Navigation Act 1912, require that an inquiry be undertaken into a marine casualty to identify the circumstances and determine the causes of the casualty. The Terms of Reference for the review, being conducted under the National Plan, of the response are attached.

(5) The Australian Maritime Safety Authority is not itself conducting an inquiry. However, as noted under response (3) above, a review is being conducted under the aegis of the National Plan Advisory Committee, members of which include representatives of each State/NT Government, AMSA and the oil, shipping and offshore exploration industries.

(6) The National Plan to Combat Pollution of the Sea by Oil sets out a clear division of responsibility for oil spill response in Australian waters. As the Iron Baron spill occurred within Tasmanian coastal waters, the Tasmanian Government has primary responsibility for the management role for the oil spill response. A number of AMSA personnel provided assistance to the Tasmanian Government during the response.

(7) AMSA is responsible for combating pollution in the marine environment by virtue of the Australian Maritime Safety Authority Act 1990. Commonwealth, State and Northern Territory Ministers comprising the Australian Transport Council have agreed that AMSA will assume management coordination of the National Plan to Combat Pollution of the Sea by Oil. AMSA is also responsible for prevention and control aspects of ship sourced pollution. This is achieved through the administration of legislation giving effect to a number of international Conventions.

(8)(a) A managing committee comprising relevant Commonwealth Government Agencies, representatives of each State/NT Government, and the oil, shipping and offshore exploration industries oversights the National Plan and advises the AMSA Board on its operation.
(b) The Plan is implemented by all National Plan members within their jurisdictions or areas of responsibility.

(9) Yes. AMSA's Melbourne area manager, Ship and Personnel Services, is a member of the group undertaking the review under the aegis of the National Plan Advisory Committee (see response to (3) above).

ANSWER.PARA: National Plan to Combat Pollution of the Sea by Oil
Review of the NATPLAN response to the Iron Baron Pollution Incident

PARA.TAB: To undertake a comprehensive assessment of the response to the Iron Baron incident which occurred following the grounding of the vessel on Hebe Reef, in the approaches to the Tamar River, northern Tasmania on Monday 10 July 1995.

The review group is to comprise persons with expertise in response to ship-sourced marine pollution incidents and related matters, but who had no role in the Iron Baron incident. Members of the review group are:
Mr Tim Muir, Navigation and Environmental Services Manager, Port of Melbourne Authority;
Mr Richard Purkiss, Executive Marine Consultant, Maritime Division, Western Australian Department of Transport;
Mr David Baird, Area Manager, Ship and Personnel Safety Services, AMSA, Melbourne;
Ms Diane Tarte, National Coordinator, Marine and Coastal Community Network;
Mr Max Laughlin (retired), former Tasmanian Director of the National Parks and Wildlife Service.

Review the circumstances of the incident from the oil pollution response perspective including the cause of the release of oil following the grounding and the vessel refloating and assess any deficiencies in the NATPLAN arrangements or in the actual response to the Iron Baron incident. In this context:
1. Assess the response by the Operations Control Committee with particular reference to:
(i) the call out procedures used and the effectiveness of the initial and subsequent response;
(ii) the suitability and accessibility of NATPLAN equipment and response capability generally;
(iii) availability and timeliness of response of technical support personnel;
(iv) the decisions made in respect of calls for equipment and personnel in regard effectiveness and timeliness;
(v) the adequacy and effectiveness of the wildlife rescue and rehabilitation response;
(vi) the adequacy and effectiveness of plans made for responding to the incident and their implementation;
(vii) the adequacy of the management of Occupational Health and Safety issues;
(viii) the adequacy of the administrative support, environmental advice and support, and other related activities;
(ix) the interaction with the media and other interested parties.

2. Assess the involvement of AMSA, the Tasmanian State Committee and other parties from the viewpoint of appropriateness, timeliness and adequacy. TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Human Services and Health, upon notice, on 3 October 1995:

PARA.TAB: (1) Is it a fact that the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission (HREOC), on 7 August 1995, found that the Australian Medical Council and the Minister had engaged in unlawful conduct in applying a quota to exclude an overseas-trained doctor, who had passed the theory examination, from proceeding to sit for the clinical examination and qualify to register as a medical practitioner.
(2) Is there any reason why this would not also apply to every other person passing the theory examination.
(3) Will steps be taken to ensure that all overseas-trained doctors who have passed the theory examination will be permitted to proceed to the clinical test.

(4) With reference to a recent decision in which HREOC referred critically to the practise of allowing the theory examination (the multiple choice question test) for registration as a medical practitioner to be available outside Australia, while many Australian citizens who passed the test here were excluded from proceeding further, and given that in light of this the HREOC wrote to the Minister `who held out the possibility of a reconsideration of government policy': Has the Government reconsidered that policy, and if so, with what results.

(5) (a) Does a quota exist limiting the number of overseas-trained doctors to 200 per year who might otherwise proceed to the clinical examination for registration as medical practitioners in this country; (b) is it a fact that many of these overseas-trained doctors are Australian citizens; (c) is it a fact that in 1995, 150 positions in that quota will be filled by doctors graduating from New Zealand Universities which have been accredited as training universities by the Australian Medical Council; (d) does the Minister consider it would be fairer if New Zealand graduates coming to Australia had a separate quota or were included in the university intake, and 200 places reserved for overseas-trained doctors living in Australia and many Australian citizens.

(6) (a) Is it a fact that hundreds of temporary resident doctors have been admitted to practise medicine in Australia in recent years, while more than 250 Australian doctors trained overseas were prevented last year from undertaking clinical tests to qualify to register as medical practitioners, and (b) why can Australian citizens not qualify when others with lesser qualifications are permitted to practise in this country.

(7) (a) Is it immigration policy to refuse working visas for persons with particular skills when those skills are in abundant supply in Australia; (b) do overseas doctors get points for their skill and so qualify to enter; and (c) are they then able to use those skills.

(8) (a) Is it a fact that the Government will spend $1 million by the time it completes its appeal against the decision of HREOC that medical quotas against overseas-trained doctors are discriminatory and unlawful; and (b) would that money be better spent eliminating discrimination rather than seeking to perpetuate it.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Human Services and Health has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) On 7 August 1995, the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission (HREOC) handed down its decision in the Siddiqui case, a complaint that the quota on the number of overseas trained doctors able to proceed to the Australian Medical Council's (AMC) clinical examination is unlawful under the Racial Discrimination Act.
The Commission found that the conduct of the AMC and Minister for Health, as a member of the Australian Health Minister's Conference (AHMC), was unlawful under Section 9(1A) of the Act.

The Commission did not find that the imposition of the quota itself amounted to direct racial discrimination. Rather it found that the manner in which the quota had been applied, was discriminatory and unreasonable for the purposes of the Act. In other words, the quota had the effect of being indirect racial discrimination.

The Commission accepted that the multiple choice question examination is a valid and legitimate method of assessing the competence of doctors. It also accepted that the restriction on undergraduate entry to Australian medical schools effectively amounted to a quota and rejected the argument that graduates from Australian medical schools are not subject to a "quota" of some kind. The Commission supported the validity of a quota on overseas trained doctors stating in its determination: "We are not persuaded that the Health Ministers acted unreasonably in determining that a quota was necessary nor in fixing it at 200 each year" and "We should observe that we reject the argument advanced for the complainant that any form of quota imposed on the admission of overseas trained doctors to registration for general practise in Australia would be discriminatory".

(2) The effect of the determination is that any overseas trained doctor who has sat the multiple choice question examination and met the minimum standard could apply to HREOC for an order that they be allowed to proceed to the clinical examination.

(3) The HREOC decision raised a number of issues which require clarification in the Federal Court and an application for an order of review has been lodged. This process will not be completed for some time. The AMC and the Commonwealth have decided to allow the 280 candidates who met the minimum performance standards in previous sittings of the multiple choice question examination to proceed through to the clinical examination. The AMC has written to these candidates to advise them of this decision.
(4) On 6 October the AMC announced that following the request from HREOC the AMC has agreed that future multiple choice question examinations will be conducted in Australia only.
(5) (a) Yes.
(b) The citizenship status of applicants is not known to the Department of Human Services and Health.

(c) New Zealand trained doctors have always been included in the target figure of 200 overseas trained doctors, from all sources, entering the Australian medical workforce each year. New Zealand trained doctors have never been included in the quota applied to candidates in the multiple choice question examination.

(d) Since the AMC accredits the two New Zealand medical schools, doctors who have gained their qualification from these institutions are not required to sit the AMC exams to gain full Australian medical registration. Under current arrangements with New Zealand, there is no restriction applied to New Zealand citizens travelling and working in Australia.

(6) (a) Doctors with temporary resident visas enter Australia to take up employment within the State and Territory health systems to fill "difficult to fill" positions on a temporary basis. These overseas trained doctors receive conditional registration to enable them to perform this role, but their stay in Australia is limited by their temporary migration status.
(b) The registration of medical practitioners is a State and Territory responsibility. Each State and Territory has its own legislation covering the registration of temporary resident doctors.

(7) (a) and (b) It is current Government policy that intending migrants whose usual occupation is that of medical practitioner be penalised 25 points in the Independent and Concessional Family points tested migration categories.

(c) To be eligible for unconditional medical registration all overseas trained doctors who become permanent residents must sit for and pass the qualification assessment exams as administered by the AMC. This is a legislative requirement of all State and Territory governments.
(8) (a) The final legal costs for the defence of the quota in HREOC and the order of review are not known as the processes are continuing.

(b) It is important that the Federal Court be given the opportunity to clarify the legal position as quickly as possible. The resolution of the appeal will determine whether programs are in fact in breach of the Racial Discrimination Act.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, upon notice, on 16 October 1995:

PARA.TAB: (1) Does the European Community require that official veterinarians conducting ante-mortem inspection of animals and post-mortem inspection of parts and carcasses in the production of fresh meat including offal for export to the European Community (EC) be employees of the Government.

(2) Has the EC given its approval to the use of third party providers to carry out the role of the `official veterinarian' under the rules set out in the Official Journal for the European Communities No. L.87 to be followed in fresh meat establishments approved for the purpose of intra-community trade.

(3) Is the department currently intending to use private veterinary inspection services on behalf of the Australian Quarantine and Inspection Service (AQIS) at establishments registered to export to the EC.

(4) If AQIS uses private veterinary practices to provide veterinary inspection services on behalf of AQIS, will the private veterinary practitioners, have authority over and be directly responsible for food standards officers carrying out on-line post-mortem inspection of carcasses and parts.

(5) Is the department currently intending to use private veterinary practices to provide veterinary inspection services on behalf of AQIS at establishments registered to export to the United States of America.

(6) If AQIS uses private veterinary practices to provide veterinary inspection services on behalf of AQIS, will food standards officers carrying out on-line post-mortem inspection be under the direct supervision of the private veterinary practitioners.

(7) If the Government intends to use private veterinary practices to provide veterinary inspection services on behalf of AQIS, what training does AQIS intend to provide to enable those private veterinary practitioners to perform the veterinary inspection services to an appropriate standard.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) The European Union does not require the actual conduct of inspection activities by Veterinarians. It does however, require certain levels of veterinary involvement depending on the inspection activity being performed.
Veterinary functions may be delivered by veterinarians not in the full-time employment of the Government, under conditions determined by the responsible Government agency.
(2) I am advised that the use of veterinarians, not in the full-time employment of Government agencies, is permitted for the purposes of intra-community trade in fresh meat.
(3) Yes.
(4) Private veterinarians, will have responsibility for those matters requiring veterinary knowledge during post-mortem inspection procedures.
(5) Yes.
(6) See answer to (4).
(7) Training will be provided appropriate to the veterinary functions for which they will have been retained.
